channel.title: Mentats of Gaming presents: Trap-a-Day
channel.description: Killing characters one trap at a time!

item.title: Carpet and Sconce Trap (CR 3)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Type magic; Perception DC 27; Disable Device DC 27

Trigger location; Reset none Effect When a character steps onto the carpet that runs down the middle of the hallway, it rolls itself up, trapping the character inside and dealing 1d6 damage. (DC 18 Reflex save negates) The character inside the carpet is pinned. (escape takes one full-round with a DC 20 Escape Artist or Strength check) Once the carpet had rolled up, the entire corridor is filled as if a Web spell has been cast at DC 12 for its effects. Once the character frees himself, or if anyone enters the web, the sconces leak oil into the webbing, setting the entire corridor ablaze and dealing 2d4 damage to all characters within the webbed area. After 1 round of being alight, the webs are destroyed and the fire is extinguished.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice!

item.title: Wallpaper Trap (CR 10)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: Type magical; Perception DC 30; Disable Device DC 30 Trigger location; Reset none Effect The wallpaper in this room depicts an epic siege of a large castle. Once the trigger point or area is activated, the siege engines on the wallpaper will fire once per round at a random character. (Primary: Ranged Atk +20 vs. AC, 4d10 damage, Secondary: 20 ft radius centered on primary attack's target, 2d10 damage, DC 17 Reflex save for half damage). The wallpaper can also be destroyed by doing 20 points of damage to it. (AC 5, hardness 1)

item.title: Erasing Scroll
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: Aura varies; CL varies Slot none; Price varies; Weight - Description This scroll appears to contain an arcane scroll. A DC 25 + spell level check will reveal that the spell listed is altered. If the spell is cast from the scroll, it will erase a random spell of the same level from memory, or use up a spell slot. If no spells or slots are available, it will use up the highest remaining spell or slot available. If the spell is copied to a spellbook, it will erase a random spell of the same level, or if not available, a random spell of the highest level available. Construction Craft Scroll, read magic, erase, dispel magic; Cost varies

item.title: Planar Wheel (CR 13)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: Aura strong conjuration, CL 13 Slot -; Price 2300 gp; Weight 50 lb Description This wagon wheel has a 25% chance of activating everytime it hits a pothole, divot or any similar irregularity on a road. When activated, the wagon, its passengers, and cargo are transported to a random plane as per the Plane Shift spell. Each character transported can resist with a successful DC 17 Will save. The wheel is a single charge item. It cannot be used for further planar travel once expended. Construction Requirements Craft Wondrous Item, Plane Shift; Cost 1150 gp

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have to say, as soon as I made this, an adventure hook popped into my head. It goes something like this: "Princess, we've freed you but we must leave in a hurry. Get in the wagon and we'll ride alongside to guard you during our escape." Thunk "Oh, crap..."

item.title: Milling door trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
Here's our first trial of a generic format that describes the trap first and then gives the rules information later. Both systemless and levelless, we'll add guidelines for specific rules systems but not specific levels. We invite readers to add numbers for specific levels and/or new rules systems.  This trap appears as - and to some extent actually is - a secret door in an apparently featureless wall, a hairline rectangular crack with a latch that can either be opened by finding and pressing a hidden pressure-pad in the centre of the "door", slid open by a thin, rigid object passing through the crack like the old credit card trick, or pushed back by magical or psychic means. However, the door is not hinged on the side. Instead, when the latch is released, it pivots around its bottom edge, as does the floor immediately in front of it and behind it, and a similar height of wall underneath the floor, like the blades of a river mill or a steamship's paddle wheel. In cross-section, it is as though a + symbol rotates through 90 degrees, with the top arm of the + being the "door" and one of the horizontal arms being where the person opening the door is standing. In other words, the floor falls out from under the person opening the "door", the "door" swings down and replaces the "floor", and another section of "floor" on the far side of the door swings up to replace the "door", latching firmly into place like the original "door". This means the mechanism automatically and endlessly resets itself unless forcibly jammed while in action. Anyone who is not cleanly within or outside the trapped floor area (such as someone attempting to open the door while not standing on the loose "floor") risks being struck by the door as it swings forwards, propelled by both the mechanism itself and the weight of whatever is on the trapped floor. It's up to you whether there actually is anything on the other side of the door, how deep the pit underneath the floor is, and what lies at the bottom - but note that the pit into which victims fall is sealed, and the trapdoor opens towards anyone trying to climb back up.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 

To spot the secret "door"

Moderate Perception

As for PFRPG

To find the latch release

Hard Perception to spot both door and mechanism, or easy Perception once door found

As for PFRPG

Accurately detect the full mechanism

Very hard Perception, or hard Perception if specifically searching floor

As for PFRPG

   

 

Meddling

 

Release the latch

Easy Disable Device

Easy Thievery

Release the latch without triggering the door to pivot (leaving it loose to be triggered by the next person to stand on the trapped floor)

Hard Disable Device

Hard Thievery

Jamming the pivot

Any object used to jam the pivot takes 6d6 initial damage (for a Huge object) plus 1d6 per round. The initial damage can be split between two objects if the pivot is jammed from both sides.

Any object used to jam the pivot takes (Level/3)d6 initial damage, and is immobilized and takes 5 ongoing damage per tier (save ends both). The initial damage can be split between two objects if the pivot is jammed from both sides.

   

 

 

Evading

 

 

To avoid falling if fully within trapped area

Very hard Reflex save; failing by less than 5 gets you trapped

Trap attacks, +(Level/2+5) vs Reflex: Hit the character suffers effects listed under falling; Miss by 5 or less the character is caught instead

To avoid being caught between floor and panel if partly outside the trapped area

Hard Reflex save; failing by 5 or more means the character is hanging by their trapped limb and risks falling when freed unless they or an adjacent ally make a hard Reflex save, or an adjacent ally has a readied action to catch them.

+Level/2 vs. Reflex: Hit the target is caught (see below). If the attack hit by 5 or more, the target falls when freed unless they make a successful saving throw or an ally has an action readied to catch them.

Effects   

 

 

Falling: forcible relocation to the area below

As described

As described

+ standard falling damage, plus optional extras depending on area below

1d6 per 10 ft.; see core rules or here for extras

1d6 per 10 ft.; see DMG and DMG2 for extras

Caught between floor and descending pivot

6d6, plus additional moderate Reflex save or arm is trapped; character is immobilized and takes 1d6 damage per round until freed by a DC 20 Strength check.

(Level/3+1)d6 damage, plus character is immobilized and takes 5 ongoing damage per tier (save ends both). An ally may spend a full-round action to lend their Strength bonus to the next save.

item.title: You can call me ray, or you can call me ray, or you can call me ray trap (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: Type magical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25; Trigger proximity (alarm); Reset none Description The room's walls and ceiling appear to be encrusted with hundreds of gems. The trap is activated once any character comes within 10 feet of the trap's location, which is usually on the floor or ceiling, centered in the room. A single ray of frost shoots out from the trap and strikes one of the gems, which is actually a magical prism that splits the ray. The other gems in the room are a mix of prisms and mirrors, further splitting and redirecting the rays. Each character in the room will be attacked by 6d6 rays. Effect Spell effect (6d6 ray of frost, +4 ranged touch atk, 1d3 damage); multiple targets (all targets in room)

item.title: Compressed Air Lock (CR 4)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: Type mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25 Trigger location; Reset manual Effect Any key or lock pick inserted into this lock is coated with black adder venom, and then fired back out at the user. Atk +11 ranged (1d3 + poison - DC 11 Fort, 1/rd for 6 rounds, 1d2 Con, cure - 1 save)

item.title: Ancient Tablet Trap (CR 10)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: An ancient stone tablet is covered in dust, obscuring the secrets revealed by its markings. Type magical; Perception DC 35 or DC 30 Knowledge Alchemy; Disable Device DC 15 Trigger location; Reset none Effect The dust, by itself, is inert. However, blowing on it transforms it into a poisonous cloud. Nightmare Vapor Cloud (1 Wisdom damage and confused for 1 round; Save DC 20 Fort; Cure 2 consecutive saves ); multiple targets (all targets in a 10-ft square)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Is this contact or inhaled poison?
Inhaled.

item.title: Porcelain Doorknob Trap (CR 1)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded: Type mechanical; Perception DC 17; Disable Device DC 17 Touch location; Reset none Effect The doorknob shatters, leaving sharp edges. Atk +8 melee (1d6)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
This is a simple, yet effective trap. Properly used, this one can change gameplay more than any of the others I've posted. If the PC's encounter one or two of these at the beginning of an adventure, it can change the way they approach doors for the course of the adventure. Also, if every door has a porcelain doorknob, the one that doesn't will be extra scrutinized. It goes to show that a trap needs not be high-level or complex to be useful.
Also, this is a trap that I've personally triggered...
Easy, simple and highly effective.

item.title: It's Better to Just Fall Trap
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap layers illusion and deception to deadly effect. The first part of the trap involves a door, which should open inwards towards the character. There is a deep, circular shaft on the other side of the door. However, this is hidden by an illusion of another room, a hallway or whatever is suitable for the location. The illusion is dispelled if the plane of the doorway is broken. At this point, the vertical drop shaft is revealed, requiring a Reflex or equivalent check to avoid falling down the shaft. The shaft itself has a ladder constructed of several iron rungs embedded into the side of the shaft, all within easy reach of the falling character. However, the rungs are actually razor-sharp blades, painted to disguise their true property. At the bottom of the shaft is a pile of bones and corpses. Scattered about the edges of the shaft are fingers, toes, and small bones; evidence of those that were quick enough to catch themselves on the rungs.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 

To spot the doorway illusion

Moderate Perception

As for PFRPG

To spot the rung blades

Very Hard Perception

As for PFRPG

Evading

 

 

To avoid falling down the shaft

Hard Reflex save

Trap attacks, +(Level/2+5) vs Reflex: Hit the character suffers effects listed under falling; Miss the character does not fall.

To avoid damage from rungs

Very Hard Reflex save

+(Level/2 +10) vs. Reflex: Hit the rungs damage the character; Miss the character takes no damage from rungs

Effects   

 

 

Falling: forcible relocation to the area below

As described

As described

+ standard falling damage, plus optional extras depending on area below

1d6 per 10 ft.; see core rules or here for extras

1d6 per 10 ft.; see DMG and DMG2 for extras

Catching the rungs

4d6, plus additional 1d3 Dex and 1d2 Con damage

(Level/3+1)d6 damage, plus character is weakened and takes 5 ongoing damage per tier (save ends both).

item.title: Dysmorphic Mirror Trap (CR 8)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Misshapen faces, carved into the frame around this silver mirror, seem to leer at any who gaze upon their own reflection.

Type: magical; Perception DC 30; Disable Device DC 30

Trigger proximity (alarm); Reset special

Effect

A character who passes within 10 feet of the mirror will notice that his reflection is slightly distorted and will suffer an attack from the mirror. Atk (1/round; DC 22 Will save negates further attacks; 1d4 Charisma dmg) With each successful attack, the character's reflection becomes progressively uglier as his Charisma is drained away. The mirror will continue to attack until either the character saves, or his Charisma reaches zero, at which point the mirror shatters. Until the mirror is destroyed, either via shattering, a successful Disable Device, or a Dispel Magic (DC 16 caster check), it will continue to activate every time a character passes within range.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Perfect for vain PC characters! I love it!

item.title: Itchy and scratchy trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: This trap works in two parts. The first part involves coating the victims-to-be in a deadly injury poison (a poison which needs to break the skin to do damage). Perhaps they have to climb through an abandoned silo filled with toxic spores, or wade through a poisonous planar swamp, or pose as cultists and be baptised in  a pool of venom. (This last option works well, as it gives players a chance to know exactly what's going on and to feel clever about not worrying about taking a bath in the stuff.) If you'd rather use disease than poison, it could even be as simple as sewer-crawling. In any case, the characters (and players) should have a moment of apprehension, but the scene should feel more like a memorable piece of narrative colour rather than Phase One of your latest dastardly scheme. Some time later, when players and characters have had a chance to forget the setup above but before they've had a chance to wash, they get exposed to itching powder. Really strong itching powder. It makes the PCs soooo itchy... If characters decide not to scratch on general principle, they may make a hard roll (in PFRPG, a DC 18 Will save) to resist the urge - this is seriously itchy stuff. They get a substantial bonus (PFRPG: +10) to this roll if they recall the stakes, i.e. that they are coated in injury poison. If you're feeling generous, and none of the players recall the danger, you might like to make a hidden roll for their characters to give them a chance to remember. Bonus Manipulative GM points if you can get the party prankster to administer the itching powder without catching on to the consequences. (Death by bedbug option: Rather than itching powder, use insect bites as the trigger.)

item.title: Like beating your head on a brick wall trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
It's Thursday: another exTRAPaganza for your GMing pleasure.  You enter a long room from a door near one end with wooden floorboards that run across the narrower width. (On the map it looks like a long horizontal rectangle with vertical stripes. Tailor the length to the speed of your PCs, but we'd suggest nothing less than 100 feet long, 20 feet wide, and with the entrace 15-20 feet from the near end, to make sure everyone is running full tilt when they hit the wall.) The only visible exit is at the far end of the room, on the narrow end. As the party enters the room, the door slams shut behind them and the floorboards appear to start falling away one at a time, starting from the near end and moving towards the PCs. This is an illusion, but as the PCs can only interact with it by waiting for it to reach them, they will almost certainly start running towards the exit at the far end. The exit's another illusion. They instead run directly into a solid wall, which is just behind the illusory wall, so that when characters hit the wall and fall unconscious this is hidden from the people behind them. The real exit is in the near end, i.e. on the other side of the growing illusory gap, and is hidden by an illusionary wall. You need to work out rules for damage based on movement speed (our suggestions are below), and it has an optional nasty secondary attack in that if you fail to disbelieve the illusion that you're falling, you take imaginary falling damage. If you're feeling really nasty, you can always put spikes on the wall...

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 
Detecting illusory nature of floor and fall N/A unless interacted with; moderate Will save when falling floorboards catch up with PC N/A unless interacted with; modelled by secondary attack, below
Detecting illusory nature of exit ahead Strictly speaking, N/A until impact; wussy merciful GMs may allow a very hard Perception check to notice a lack of airflow, which reduces the Reflex save to halve the damage to merely hard. Strictly speaking, N/A until impact; merciful GMs may allow a very hard Perception check to notice a lack of airflow. A successful check reduces the attack vs Reflex from very hard to hard.

Evading

 

 
Breaking down the door by which they entered and leaving that way in time Hard Strength check, or attack vs normal door stats; those who hope to react in time need to make a hard Reflex save, with a -2 penalty for each person closer to the door than they are. Hard Strength check, or a single attack vs. moderate AC which must deal 15hp/tier to destroy the door. Those who hope to react in time need to make a hard Dex check, with a -2 penalty for each person closer to the door than they are.

Effects   

 

 
Running into a stone wall head first [NB "running speed" refers to the total distance a character can cover per when running flat out] 1d6 damage per 20' of running speed (so for a standard, unencumbered character, with base speed 30' and running speed of 120', 6d6), and a -4 penalty to Will and stunned for 1 round per 20' of running speed. Very hard Reflex save for half damage and a -2 penalty to Will instead, then staggered for 1 round per 20' of running speed. Very hard attack vs. Reflex.Hit: 1d10 per 20' of running speed, and you are stunned and take -4 to Will (save ends). Aftereffect: dazed and take -2 to Will (save ends).Miss: 1d10 per 40' of running speed, and you are dazed and take -2 to Will (save ends).
Believing you're falling into an illusory pit Moderate Will save or take falling damage for the depth of the illusory pit (1d6 per 10'). If you have just run headfirst into a wall, take -4 on the save. Moderate attack vs. Will or take falling damage for the depth of the illusory pit (1d10 per 10'). If you have just run headfirst into a wall, you have a -4 penalty to your Will defense.

item.title: Tendon Slicing Snare (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
As you make your way through the forest, the dense ground cover slows your progress to a crawl.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 28; Disable Device DC 18

Trigger location; Reset manual

Effect

This snare trap is made of a thin filament of sharp wire. When a character is caught, it bites into the ankle deeply, slicing muscle and tendons. (2d6 damage + 1d3 Dex damage and character is entangled and slowed to half his movement speed. He remains entangled until he frees himself with a DC 25 Escape Artist or Acrobatics check, or a second character can free the trapped character by expending a full round action to free him. The slowed condition remains until the Dex damage is healed.); DC 25 Reflex avoids.

item.title: Hall of Flags (CR 7)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The flags of many nations line the walls of this hallway, each hanging motionless from its pole.

Type: magical; Perception DC 27; Disable Device DC 27

Trigger proximity (alarm); Reset none

Effect

When the door at the end of the hall is opened, it triggers a gust of wind, which causes each flag to unfurl, spreading Burnt Othur Fumes throughout the hallway. Burnt Othur Fumes (1/round for 6 rounds, Initial 1 Con drain, Secondary 1d3 Con Drain, Cure 2 Consecutive Saves at DC 18 Reflex); multiple targets (all targets in hallway)

item.title: Razor belt (the “it’s a cinch” trap)
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
This belt consists of a normal belt buckle and a normal belt end, firmly attached to magically sharp wires (or monofilaments in a scifi game) which then have the middle section of the belt sewn around them. When the belt is pulled tight prior to buckling, the viciously sharp strands slice through first their sheathing and then the victim's body with so little resistance that the victim is likely to suspect that the belt has broken before they realise the terrible wounds they have received.
These belts are commonly designed to look like potent magical/tech items, and the wealthier sadist will even go so far as to make the belt and then apply genuine enchantments or tech to ensure that it gets worn. Failing that, they are usually of exceptional quality and/or a fashionable make, to snare dandies.
The same basic mechanism can be applied to chokers, ties on sweatpants, sandal straps, corsets – anything that loops around a part of the character's body and gets drawn tight against what it encircles.
In the PFRPG ruleset, a CR 10 version of this trap would have a DC 27 Perception check to notice the trap, and it would deal 12d6 damage when tightened. You might prefer to vary this to (10+Str mod)d6 - particularly cruel on a trapped Belt of Giant Strength.

item.title: Short Sword of Clumsiness
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
This fine sword has an intricately inlaid hilt and pommel.

The guard on this sword is hinged (DC 35 Perception check to spot) and folds up against the blade.

Effect

On a successful hit, the wielder must make a DC 15 Strength check or lose his grip, causing his hand to slide up through the guard onto the blade, dealing 1d3 Dex damage.

item.title: Spell Pouch of Spontaneous Casting
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
This spell pouch is made of fine leather, with velvet designs sewn onto it with golden thread.

This pouch provides an unlimited supply of spell reagents at will. However, there is a chance during spellcasting of triggering a spellstorm.

Effect

Whenever a spell that requires a "to hit" roll (check or attack) is an automatic hit (20) or automatic miss (1) there is a chance that a spellstorm is triggered. A DC 10 + spell level caster check must be made or else the spellstorm is triggered. If a spellstorm is triggered, every remaining prepared spell, in alphabetical order, is cast at the same target of the spell that triggered the storm. The casting of these spells happen in the same round, then the character's turn ends. These spells are consumed from the character's daily allotment.

item.title: Corrosive Floor (CR 2)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The floor tiles in this room are cracked and disintegrating.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 27 Knowledge Dungeoneering; Disable Device -

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

When the tiles are stepped on, clouds of dust are raised up into the air. For every 10' moved, the clouds have a chance of causing AC damage to non-magical metal armor and shields, and a damage penalty to non-magical metal weapons. Should the AC or damage penalty exceed the original AC or damage modifier, the equipment is destroyed. Corrosion attack (+4 vs. touch AC, 1d6 AC damage to non-magical, metal armor, 1d3 damage penalty to non-magical, metal weapons)

item.title: Ale and Nut Trap
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is for all those drunks we call adventurers that think they can scam free beer whenever it is found. The players come across a room at the bottom of stairs that is an ale house. It has a bar, kegs, tables and chairs. The bar and tables have tankards and bowls full of peanuts on top of them. When the keg is tapped, the entrance to the room at the top of the stairs is sealed. Feel free to use whatever type of door. The harder to open, the deadlier the trap. For maximum effect, if the characters try to escape the room via the door, they should be dealing with it while under the level of the beer. Beer begins to pour on the floor and fills the room at the rate of 1 foot per round. If a character drinks a tankard full every round, the level of the beer will not rise. At some point, Fortitude saves will be necessary to keep drinking and not pass out. The only way to stop the beer is to shell the peanuts and throw them in the beer. It requires 1 peanut for every 1' of beer. If checked, the peanuts radiate magic, and if the GM feels kind, the characters can use the peanuts outside of this room to absorb liquid.

item.title: Blockaded, Mesh Reinforced Door (CR 8)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
This door has been boarded and barricaded shut.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 35; Disable Device DC 25

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

item.title: Ethereal Band (CR 10)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The walls and floor of this hallway are exceptionally smooth.

Type: magical; Perception DC 27; Disable Device DC 27

Trigger proximity (alarm); Reset none

Effect

The back wall of this room is covered in small spikes. (DC 25 Perception check to notice casually if not actively looking). As soon as a character enters the room, he begins to stretch an invisible, incorporeal band anchored at a slight offset on each side of the hallway. Once the character reaches the halfway point of the room, the band becomes substantial, hurling the character towards the back of the hallway and into the spiked wal. Additionally, there is a chance that any other character behind will get hit by the flying character. Band Attack (6d6+6 damage, DC 21 Reflex negates) Flying character attack (3d6+3 damage, DC 18 Reflex negates)

item.title: (Don't you step on my) Glueskin Ooze (hazard)
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: Many adventurers are familiar with the sinking feeling of stepping onto the floor of a dungeon room, being unable to move their feet, and looking down to realise that they have stepped onto a thin layer of glue. Well, maybe not many, but some. Almost none are familiar with the sight of that glue being roused from slumber by the pressure and heat of their body, gathering around them, and slithering up their bodies, like reverse slow-motion of water running off someone who just climbed out of a river. And that's because those who have seen (and felt) this happen usually suffocate shortly thereafter, as the glue oozes its way into their nostrils and down into their torsos. Dormant between feeds, glueskin ooze slowly spreads out to fill the available floor area. Like its cuboid cousin, it is clear and very difficult to spot. It is incredibly sticky; lifting a foot off the ooze requires a tremendous feat of strength (pun not intended) or the removal of footwear. (In PFRPG/D&D 4E terms, a Strength check as a standard action allows movement of 5 feet, and the character is slowed until they can clear the dregs of the ooze off their shoes/feet.) When triggered by pressure, especially accompanied by body heat, it starts to gather itself around whatever has landed on it. On an average-sized human, it achieves knee height within ten seconds, and complete coverage in a minute, at which point the victim starts running out of air. The victim is then digested at leisure; the process takes several hours. Should a victim of the ooze not be subject to suffocation, by dint of magic or simply not needing to breathe, they take 1 hp of damage per minute and cannot recover the hit points while the ooze remains bonded to them. If the ooze enters an open wound, it also weakens them (the character also takes 1 Con damage, or loses 1 healing surge, per minute). The ooze has two weaknesses. First, it is quite flammable, but for most victims this is somewhat undesirable as a method of removal. Second, it finds rock oil profoundly repellent; while the noxious black goop doesn't harm it per se (unless of course it's burning), the ooze will not expand across any surface coated with it, and will withdraw from any surface to which it is applied. This has resulted in one particularly ingenious (and strong) adventurer coating his face with oil to prevent the ooze from suffocating him, allowing the ooze to coat his body, and then using his newly-adhesive limbs to climb out of the pit into which he had fallen. (PFRPG/D&D 4E: the character is treated as having spider climb active, allowing them to move up sheer vertical surfaces - when they can actually manage to move.)

item.title: If I've seen it once, I've seen it a hundred times trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
ExTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series, strikes again (and again and again)... This is one for those of you with groups interested in playing with memory. The trap consists of a long stretch of enchanted corridor. The first enchanted section acts as a kind of save point; the PCs are ensorcelled at this point, although the magic doesn't trigger until an enchanted PC crosses the second section of the enchantment. When they do, or if they don't after a set period has elapsed, they (a) teleport back to the "save point" where they entered the trap and (b) forget everything that has happened since they left it. These effects trigger simultaneously when every PC has succumbed. The main challenge of this trap consists of working out what's going on, because the subjective experience of the PCs is of course that time suddenly passes in the same spot. Rather than remembering the hundred times they've walked down the corridor, they only know that suddenly their legs are really tired, and they're exhausted and hungry. The trap will be more intriguing and memorable if the PCs are confronted with an anomaly which they must resolve. For this reason, we suggest that the trap automatically hit unless there is a compelling reason for it not to (such as immunity to teleportation or memory modification) until enough time has passed that a minor but noticeable inconvenience or mystery has arisen - the PCs are becoming fatigued, for instance, or they suddenly need to eat, or a just-lit torch is starting to gutter, or footprints (the party's of course) have suddenly appeared in the dust in front of them. This inconvenience need not be an actual mechanical penalty - just something noticeable enough to warrant breaking the loop of walking down the corridor, being teleported back, forgetting that they've already walked down the corridor, and automatically starting out again. On the other end of the scale, they might even have unexplained injuries and damage to armour, from now-forgotten combats. Either way, if you are going to introduce such an element of GM fiat, you should not do so where the time lost to the trap will cost the PCs their objective - though heightening the sense of jeopardy is of course perfectly fine. At this point, you might allow a standard mechanical resolution (such as a Will save to resist the magic, or treating the spell as an attack vs Will), or you might force the party to think it out and somehow arrange to leave themselves warning, or defeat the triggering of the "reset", the next time through. Having some PCs succeed in resisting the trap and others fail is an interesting way to split the party - do those now free from the trap venture back in to try and bring out their friends? Or perhaps, if the PCs are questing for a particular small, valuable item, they now already have it in their possession - but have no memory of this fact, and set out to secure it a second time. Working out the trap reveals not only the cause of their predicament, but that they have already suceeded. This plot twist could bear considerable fruit down the track - possibly they now have a friend or a sworn enemy they don't recall ever meeting. If your group is amenable, you could turn this into a game in role-playing - they are given six seconds (or twenty, or however long) of their character's thought process, which they must use to convince you that this time they will work it out. This might confer a bonus to rolls, or it might allow for outright solving the trap.

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 
 On first encounter Detect magic through a magic aura disguise Arcana-based skill challenge
After given evidence suggestive of its existence (minor: a sudden sense of fatigue or pain in the legs; major: a candle is suddenly burned down) As above, or a hard Intelligence check, +2 for each minor piece of evidence and +5 for compelling evidence  As for PFRPG

item.title: Cardsharp's reversal, or, That's not a papercut - THIS is a papercut
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
Possibly a cursed item that is apparently enchanted to secure big wins, and indeed does so, but goes off immediately after helping its owner to a major haul; or possibly a nasty weapon to be used by a gambler who doesn't like the way the game is going, the cardsharp's reversal is a deck of cards where the aces of each suit are modified in such a way that the edges can become razor-sharp mid-shuffle, and the cards themselves a little larger and substantially heavier - perhaps they even transform into slightly-larger-than-card-sized razors.

In PFRPG terms, this transformation triggers a Reflex save vs DC 25. On a successful save, the victim takes 2d6 damage plus 1d6 bleed, and a -2 penalty on all Dexterity- based checks involving the hands until the previous damage is healed. On a failed save, the target loses 1d6 fingers: in addition to the above effects, for each finger lost there is a further permanent -1 penalty to the aforementioned checks and to checks pertaining to grip strength (eg disarm checks) until the fingers can be reattached, regrown or replaced, presumably with a regeneration spell or similar. This penalty reduces by 1 for each level gained, as the character learns to compensate, but never to less than half its original value, rounded up. A hand that has lost enough digits may lose the ability to grip altogether.

item.title: Let me g- NO DON'T trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
The PCs are climbing down a high cliff on vines, when some of the vines attack them. Use a standard creature such as an assassin vine, or treat it as a Reflex save against DC 20 to avoid being immobilized and taking 2d6 constriction damage per round. The trap part comes from the fact that the PCs cannot be overzealous in destroying the vines, lest they fall - give a vine 15 hp and hardness 3, and if the vine is destroyed, any PC being held by it must make a Reflex save against a DC equal to the number of negative hp the vine now has or they fall.

On the plus side, if a PC falls past a patch of vine trap, the vines reflexively try to snare them - give the vines a raw d20 roll against a target number equal to half the number of feet fallen. If the vines hit, the PC takes quarter the normal falling damage and is immobilized as above. If the vines miss by less than 5, the PC can make a Reflex save against the same target number to grab the vines and halt their fall, taking the quarter falling damage, but not ending up immobilized. If the vines miss by more than 5, the PC simply continues falling.

Alternatively: the PCs are climbing a ladder and the ladder animates. (This is especially apt for places with a snake motif to their fixtures.) If you use this variant, give the ladder 20hp and hardness 8, and be ready for/with the Snakes & Ladders jokes.

item.title: Learn not to trust the villain trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: This trap works well in conjunction with (or shortly after) the previous trap. It consist of an identical button, also marked emphatically DO NOT PRESS. At some point the room in which it sits becomes a slow-acting deathtrap - perhaps water starts flooding in, or gas, or the room is sealed and air starts running out. In any case, pressing the button will deactivate the trap, but hopefully the PCs are sufficiently spooked that they won't do it. In PFRPG, you might allow a DC 30-35 Disable Device check to ascertain the true nature of the button, but if so, roll secretly so the PCs are not quite sure whether a 1 was rolled. A strongly "psych-out" trap like this, especially one prefaced by one or more instances of the "learn to read" trap, indicates a consciously manipulative trap designer, someone who is trying to prove that they are cleverer than their victims. As a guaranteed deathtrap it is rather inefficient, but as a statement of malice and declaration of psychological warfare it is highly effective.

item.title: Beware the cliche trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: This trap consists of a long bookshelf along one wall in a room that the PCs expect to have a secret passage. One book is particularly incongruous (Courtship rituals of the lesser Mozambican gerbil) and sticking out from the shelf slightly (Perception 13 to notice). If pulled, it causes the entire ten-foot-tall bookshelf to slam forwards onto the ground within 10' of the wall on which the shelves are mounted. (Perception 23 to spot the hinges and possibly some very faded bloodstains on the carpet; DC 23 skill check to disable the trap or set it off slowly; in PFRPG, 6d6 bludgeoning damage with Reflex 23 to take no damage, or 20 for half damage; in M&M3E, a bludgeoning attack with a +13 bonus.) The trap also covers the real secret exit - a trapdoor which is now under the bookshelves. (DC 28 to notice it before this, as it's under a rug.) If through some incredible fluke a PC is standing on the trapdoor when the trap hits them, the trapdoor takes as half much damage as the PC, and if that exceeds its 15 hp, it collapses under them. It's up to you how far they fall and what they find.

item.title: Cannon in the Floor
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is for all those adventurers that insist on going through every opening. The players enter a room that has a person-sized opening in the floor, slanted at about a 45 degree angle. They can't see the bottom. The opening is a smooth tube that goes down about 30 feet. If the characters check, the bottom is somewhat blackened. Above the hole, there are faint blood stains and an even fainter image of a bulls-eye target. The tube is filled with an odorless, colorless, heavy, slow-igniting, combustible gas that has mostly pooled towards the bottom. There is a small chance of igniting the gas if a flame is placed in the tube as a character looks down. If a character enters the tube, he will slide towards the bottom, where he will find bones and other bits of debris. If he has any kind of flame with him, he will have a chance of igniting the gas that goes up progressively as he nears the bottom. When the gas is ignited, it will fire him and anything else in the tube towards the ceiling. If the gas is ignited before the character is in the tube, he will be hit by the "grapeshot" at the bottom of the tube.

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

To detect the bloodstains and target on the ceiling

Hard Perception

As for PFRPG

To detect the gas

Very Hard Perception

As for PFRPG
To detect the debris at the bottom Hard Perception As for PFRPG

Igniting Gas

 

 

From outside of the tube

Low (< 20%)

As for PFRPG

From inside the tube

Progressive with 100% chance at bottom

As for PFRPG

Effects   

 

 

Debris Blast from outside

Cone shaped attack to ceiling. Moderate Reflex save for half damage. Damage should be around 1d6 per APL.

Close Burst 3 vs. Reflex with moderate bonus, miss for half damage. Damage should be 1d6 per average PC level plus 5 ongoing bleed damage per tier. (save ends)

Debris Blast from inside

High Reflex save for half damage. Damage should be around 1d6+3 per APL.

Attack vs. Reflex with high bonus, miss for half damage. Damage should be around 1d6+3 per average PC level + 5 ongoing bleed damage per tier. Character is also dazed.

Cannon Damage from inside

Extremely High Reflex save for half damage. Damage should be around 3d6 per APL, and character lands on the floor in a random spot within 10 feet of the opening, and if the save was failed, is prone.

Attack vs. Reflex with extremely high bonus, miss for half damage. Damage should be around 3d6 per average PC level. The character lands randomly within 2 squares of the opening and is knocked prone, deafened (save ends) and stunned. (save ends)

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 20; Disable Device DC 20

Trigger touch; Reset none

item.title: I'm the Target? (CR 8)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A beautiful bow and a full quiver of arrows lean against the wall. Down range, several arrows have pierced the bulls-eye.

Type: magical; Perception DC 29; Disable Device DC 29

Trigger use; Reset until disabled

Effect

If the bow is fired at the target, the arrow will always hit the bullseye. However, 1d6 arrows will fly back at the character wielding the bow. Arrow Atk (+20 Ranged, 1d8+1 damage); multiple attacks (1d6 arrows). The bow does not function unless fired at the target.

item.title: Remember, *Don't* Walk on the Left Side (or the Right)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is for all those adventurers that want to circumvent your carefully crafted obstacles. The players enter a large room, with another door on the opposite the one they entered. Large metal spheres bounce up and down in the middle of the room, in a line from door to door. They are spaced out evenly, about 10 feet apart. The floor of the room is in its own gravity field. Once in the room, gravity is relative to the floor. However, this is not the case underneath the floor. The floor itself sits balanced on a long beam, straight down the center, from door to door. If a character, or other weight, is placed anywhere other than down the centerline, the floor will shift. The further out the weight is put, the more the floor will shift. At the edges, it will shift a full 90 degrees. While this won't affect a character on the floor too much, it will affect other characters entering or exiting the room, and more importantly, it will affect the metal spheres. The metal spheres will hit the walls and ceilings and bounce all over the floor, creating a deadly hailstorm of metal, and also causing the floor to rotate wildly.

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 

To detect gravity difference from outside room

Very Hard Perception to Easy Perception as floor shifts

As for PFRPG

To detect gravity difference from within room

Very Hard Perception to Easy Perception as floor shifts

As for PFRPG
To detect the floor shift Very Hard Perception to Easy Perception as floor shifts As for PFRPG

Entering/Exiting Room

 

 

Entering Room

Easy Acrobatics Check

As for PFRPG

Easy Athletics to Hard Athletics as floor shifts

Effects   

 

 

Bouncing Spheres no Floor Shift

Moderate Acrobatics check to avoid a single sphere. Damage should be around 1d12 per APL.

Moderate Acrobatics check to avoid a single sphere. Damage should be around 1d12 per average PC level.

Bouncing Spheres with Floor Shift

Area attack in entire chamber. High Reflex save to avoid damage. Damage should be around (1d6) * (1d8) per APL. Movement speed in room is halved.

Burst attack vs. Reflex with high bonus, miss for no damage. Damage should be around (1d6) * (1d8) per average PC level. Entire room is treated as difficult terrain.

item.title: Off-Hand Gloves (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
These gloves appear to be made from supple, expensive leather. Subtle designs, woven in golden thread, weave around the fingers.

Type: magical; Perception DC 30; Disable Device DC 30

Trigger touch; Reset none

Effect

These gloves, when worn, switch the wearers right and left hands. (DC 18 Fortitude negates) All actions that involve motion (melee and ranged attacks, somatic spellcasting, Dex checks, etc) suffer a -4 penalty. A polymorph spell or remove curse will shift the hands back.

item.title: Tower of Augery
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is for all those adventurers that think they can just march up to whatever they want with no consequences. The victims... err, adventurers come across an underground tower in a cavern that is rumored to contain the vast wealth and treasure of a wizard or lich. The tower has a single entrance at ground level, a solid iron portal or some such. It should be mildly challenging to gain entry, perhaps even trapped. Once they get inside, they see a hollow, windowless tower, with a spiral staircase curving its way around the inside walls and stretching up to the top of the tower, which is just out of sight. Once the characters start climbing the stairs, it activates the trap. The stairs cause the top and bottom of the tower to silently raise and lower. The bottom augers its way into the ground, and the top drills into the cavern ceiling. The entire inside of the tower, including the floor, move. Each step the characters take drills the floor further into the ground and the top of the tower further into the ceiling. After several steps, the entrance at the bottom of the tower will be hopelessly buried under the earth. The cavern itself is underneath a large subterranean lake. At some point, the top of the tower will drill into the bottom of the lake, filling the tower with thousands of gallons of water, unless the lake was made of lava or acid, that is. The only way out of the tower, once the entrance is buried is to use a mode of travel that does not use the stairs to reach a higher-than-ground-level height. At this point, the wall of the tower itself must be breached to escape. You can make this easier/harder by varying the thickness and materials of the wall.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 

To detect the drilling motion

Very Hard Perception (bonus for dwarves)

As for PFRPG

To detect the fact that the ceiling is getting further away

Very Hard Perception to Easy Perception as more steps are taken

As for PFRPG
To detect the imminent collapse of the ceiling Hard Perception (bonus for dwarves) As for PFRPG

Effects   

 

 

Ceiling Collapse

This dumps thousands of gallons of liquid into the tower. If it is water, the characters will take a high amount of damage, something like 10d10 Reflex based damage. Afterwards, std drowning rules apply. Other, more dangerous liquids (lava, acid, etc) are pretty much going to add more damage, and be instant death unless precautions have been taken.

As for PFRPG

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Could it be named anything else? I think not.

item.title: Taut Tripwire (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:

The tripwire supports two support beams on the other side of each wall. If the device is tripped over or disabled, the side walls collapse. If the wire is not seen, it will do its trip attack. Trip Atk (triggers wall collapse, DC 15 Reflex avoids). Wall Collapse (3d6+3 damage, DC 20 Reflex for half); multiple targets (all targets in room).

item.title: The Vault
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is for all those rogues who think they are useful by disarming traps, opening locks, etc... The characters enter a large room with a vault door, secured with a complex combination lock. The dial of the lock is labelled with runes that are in draconic (or abyssal, whatever suits your needs). To open the lock, 3 progressively harder, successive Open Locks or Thievery checks are made. All 3 must be made to disable the trap. If any of the checks fail, the character will not know, and can keep going. At this point, the door to the vault can be opened. Depending on how many successes they had, 0-3 traps will be set off, in order. If all 3 checks failed, resolve traps 1-3 in order, if 2 checks failed, resolve traps 1 & 2, if 1 check failed, resolve trap 1, and if no checks failed, there are no traps triggered. Trap #1 - The floor of the room outside of the vault opens into a 10' deep spiked pit. Trap #2 - The ceiling closes, raining down poisonous dye. Trap #3 - The entire pit becomes instantly filled with a giant gelatinous cube.

item.title: Belt-and-suspenders spiked ceiling trap
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: This trap does the same thing two different ways - and must therefore be spotted and disarmed twice. It consists of a 10'-square floor slab in a 10'-wide corridor, directly below a concealed hole in the ceiling with spikes at the top. When stepped upon, the slab slams upwards, bashing through the thin cover on the hole and impaling victims on the spikes. Underneath the slab there is a spring mechanism which forces the slab upwards and is triggered by the addition of extra weight. There is also a triggered spell trap affecting the slab, which casts reverse gravity when the slab is stepped on, causing it (and anyone on it) to fall upwards onto the spikes. Spotting either trap has a Perception DC of 28, and disarming either trap has a DC of 28. Both versions of the trap do 6d6 bludgeoning and 5d6 piercing damage - this isn't doubled if neither version has been disarmed. The only complication of the trap is that it requires 2 successful checks to notice and to disarm.

item.title: Waste Disposal (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The bricks of the sewer are old and some of them are loose. A stream of humanity's excrement runs down the middle.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

A section of the sewer floor collapses when it is stepped upon. Floor Collapse (Character falls through floor; DC 25 Reflex negates). The character falls into a lower, fast moving stream. In order to get back out, the character must spend one round swimming in the correct direction(DC 20 Perception check and DC 20 Swim check), and then must climb out (DC 20 Climb check). If the Perception or Swim check fails, the character may try again, but at +5 DC to both checks for each failure. If the character fails to climb out, he may make a DC 20 Strength check to hang onto the opening and not get swept back into the river. Apply std drowning rules, as the character is underwater.

item.title: Lever Trap (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A lever is set into the floor in front of a spiked portcullis.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25

Trigger touch; Reset none

Effect

When the lever is touched, it traps the hand and throws the character forward into the spiked portcullis, which then raises into the ceiling, which is spiked.. Lever Atk (3d6+3 damage + Secondary Atk, DC 25 Reflex negates); Secondary Atk (+10 Melee, 3d6+3 damage).

item.title: Parlor from Hell
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is, well, frankly, just annoying. The characters enter a large room, full of music boxes, clocks and other curious. Every square inch of available surface area has some kind of musical knick-knack on it. Once the characters are in the room, the entrances and exits simply disappear, as the room is phased into a different dimension or plane. At this point, every single piece of kitch in the room begins to play the same tune, albeit slightly out of time, creating crazy cacophony of sound. The characters must synchronize every device in the room to make the room re-materialize to its original location.

item.title: Void Curtains (CR 8)

item.title: Grate Trap (CR 2)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A heavy metal grate, set into the floor, bars the entrance to an underground passage.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 20; Disable Device DC 20

Trigger location; Reset none

When the grate is lifted, the area within a 10' square around it collapses, revealing a 10' long serrated slide. Slide and Collapse Atk (4d4+4 damage plus character is knocked prone, DC 20 Reflex save avoids); multiple targets (all targets within 10' square).

item.title: CarWash
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was sitting in my car, watching the carwash brushes and nozzles going, and it got me to thinking. This kind of thinking generally does not bode well for players. The characters enter a long hallway. If they are observant, they may notice some small features, like crooked bricks, worn spots or scorch marks on the floor or walls. Once they are all inside, the floor begins to move forward, and carries the party through a series of traps. The first trap shoots out water that magically causes metal to rust. For the second trap, fans of blades rotate from the walls, ceiling and floor. The third trap rewards the party with a poison rinse. The fourth trap dries everyone off with flame jets. The fifth trap coats the characters in a special wax which sucks the moisture out of their bodies. The sixth and final trap covers the characters in sticky towels which stick to them and suffocate. There is an optional jar at the end of the hallway for tips. Feel free to have a few copper pieces placed in there.

D&D 4e:

Detecting   

 

 

Trap #1 - Rust Water Jet

Hard Perception

Moderate Perception

As for PFRGP

Moderate Perception

As for PFRGP

Moderate Perception

As for PFRGP

Trap #5 - Wax

Hard Perception

As for PFRGP

Very Hard Perception

As for PFRGP

Effects

 

 

Trap #1 - Rust Water Jet

Hard Reflex Save to avoid contact. Hard Fortitude save to avoid Rust effect (as Rust Monster attack in Bestiary)

item.title: Rats in a Maze
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This "trap" shows that you don't really need traps of the traditional sense to produce tension. The characters end up in some kind of maze. It could be a brick maze, a hedge maze, anything that is convenient. The important thing is that once they are in, they can't get out by any means other than traversing the maze. Oh, I suppose they could use some kind of dimensional travel, but if you are mean, you can have them end up in a shadow maze in whatever dimension they end up in. Make the maze long and complicated, and make it have only one correct route. Sprinkle liberally with dead ends, wrong turns and the occasional remains of a past party. The characters can try to navigate this normally, or they can use Survival and/or Dungeoneering/Wilderness type checks as appropriate. In a d20 based system, each intersection should be assigned a DC to figure out how to proceed, as per guidelines in the table below. If the characters choose the correct route, nothing happens. If they don't, they are hit with various spells, ranging from magic missiles and fireballs to stinking clouds and fatiguing rays. Note that if the characters get punished for going the wrong direction, they won't get punished again until the next directional choice. So, for example, the characters run into a ladder going up and down. They choose the wrong direction and go down. They are hit with a damaging spell. Instead of going back up, they continue in the lower level until they come across a T-intersection. They go left. Once they go left, they are hit with another damaging spell. The only way to stop the spells is to get back to the correct path.

D&D 4e:

Moderate Survival, Nature or Dungeoneering (depending on terrain)

item.title: Trapestry
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: This fine silken tapestry appears to depict some sort of prophecy, or at least very flattering image, involving the PCs. Tailor this to your campaign, but embroider your description to give them as much reason as possible to take the thing with them. However, PCs who touch the tapestry must make a Fortitude save (DC 15 for a brief touch, DC 18 if the tapestry is gripped fully, DC 20 if it is held for more than a few seconds, and DC 25 if it covers them). Those who fail find that they cannot put the tapestry down - their flesh has taken on a woven texture and merged into the threads of the tapestry. The process is painless and the tapestry may be willing to relinquish its grasp at any particular point, so PCs can move their grips around freely - it's only letting go altogether that it won't allow. An immediate DC 20 Strength check allows victims who are only holding the tapestry to pull their hands free, but deals 1 hp of damage per HD/level and imposes a -4 penalty to Strength-, Dexterity- or Constitution-based checks involving the hands (for instance, Disable Device checks or Fortitude saves to resist a contact poison touched with the raw skin of the hands). Over the next round the woven texture spreads up the PC's arms; after 5 rounds it covers them completely, and after that they begin to be unwoven and absorbed into the tapestry. (For visual reference, think of knitting unravelling combined with a sort of textile version of Jeff Bridges being scanned and uploaded in Tron.) Thereafter the trapestry's victims are visible in it - you never see them move, but when you blink they are in a different location. The effects of this trap may be more narrative in nature - you might allow PCs to quest through the woven world for a way to unweave the enchantment that binds them. You may allow the setback to confer them benefits in the overall plot - for instance, perhaps they can travel between tapestries (through weft-space), allowing them to see out into the real world from the tapestries that show their current location, and even (once they've worked out how to escape) allowing them to exit into an otherwise impenetrable fortress. Or you could simply treat it as a modified flesh to stone effect - flesh to thread - and allow a magical cure.

item.title: The Floured Armory
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is, well, kind of silly. Plus I'm going to bake something this weekend, anyway. The characters enter a large room with a diffuse, fine powder in the air. It covers absolutely everything, including the crates and barrels all along the walls, as well as the armored statues spread throughout the room. If the characters just wander through the room, and don't disturb anything, they will be fine. However, once they start poking through the crates and barrels, the guardians will activate. The guardians really do no damage. They will attack the characters, but a single melee hit kills them. (they are immune to just about everything but good, old-fashioned weapon damage) The deal here, though, is that the guardians are all coated in a special oil that ignites upon any impact. This, in turn, reacts with the otherwise inert powder which flash burns. Did I mention that the crates and barrels are filled with gunpowder and all sorts of other unstable material? Cause those explode too, once the powder ignites.

Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was going through some of my old 8-bit stuff and ran across Pinball Construction Set. A trap was born shortly thereafter. The party enters a large cave. The cave slopes upward and is filled with 30 giant, colorful mushrooms. At some point, a boulder rolls out from the far side of the cavern. It will hit 1d6 random mushrooms until it reaches the opening where the characters entered the cavern. At this point, 2 walls of force will activate and bounce the boulder back into the cavern, where it will hit 1d6 more random mushrooms and repeat. Each mushroom, when hit, creates a special, damaging effect and is then destroyed. Each mushroom's attack will target 1d4 characters in the cavern. The trap runs until the boulder escapes (one or both walls of force removed) or all the mushrooms are gone.

item.title: Legolas You Ain't (CR 7)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A long, long staircase descends in front of you. Long. Really.

Type: magical; Perception DC 29; Disable Device DC 29

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

Near the top of the stairs, a large tower shield has been placed and hidden by an illusion. When you step on it, it will start to slide down. About halfway down the stairs, several razor thin wires, at various heights from high to low have been placed. One of them should catch the head. Shield Slide (DC 25 Reflex save to avoid or start sliding down the stairs. There is an adhesive that causes feet to stick to the shield - or any body part). Wire attack (3d6 (6d6 if on shield) damage; +10 melee (+15 if on shield); A critical hit decapitates target) When the shield reaches the bottom of the stairs, it crashes into a wall. Wall Attack (2d6 falling damage).

item.title: Don't Go in the Attic (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A rope is attached to a trap door in the ceiling.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

If the rope is pulled, the trap door opens to reveal stairs. It also dumps a cauldron of molten iron on top of you, too. Molten Iron Attack (6d6 fire damage; DC 25 Reflex for half damage); multiple targets (All targets in a 15' line)

item.title: Coin Room (CR 18)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
This bare stone room is empty except for the ginormous pile of coins in the middle.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 31; Disable Device DC 31

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The pile of coins sits atop a weight activated mechanism. When enough weight (i.e. coins) are moved from the pile, the mechanism activates, which disengages the locks holding the one piece stone block ceiling in place, causing it to fall. Falling Stone Ceiling (20d6 damage, DC 34 Reflex avoids); multiple targets (all targets in room)

item.title: Chandelier Room (CR 3)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The Hall is brightly lit by the thousands of large candles populating the hundreds of chandeliers hanging from the ceiling. Two sets of great double doors are at either end of the hall.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 18; Disable Device DC 22

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

Either set of the doors sets off the trap once the characters are in the room. When the doors are opened, a gust of wind blows all the chandeliers, dripping wax from the thousands of candles onto the party. Hot wax attack (1d6+3 damage, DC 17 Reflex for half damage); multiple targets (all targets in room)

item.title: Fuse Rope (CR varies)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A rope is attached to the side of the cliff and goes all the way down to the base of the cliff where it is tied off.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 15

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The rope is actually a long fuse. If it is used to climb down the cliff, the motion on the bottom will create a spark and ignite the rope, which quickly burns. The character will be about halfway down the cliff when it activates. The cliff can be whatever height x(10ft) that you choose. Rope Fuse (xd6 falling damage, DC 20 Reflex allows character to cling to side of cliff) A DC 30 climb check will allow the character to descend the rope without setting it alight.

item.title: Plane Old Dungeon
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I think this trap is just meant to be annoying. The party enters a house, dungeon cavern whatever with long, dimly lit corridors or passages. Each time the travel between "rooms" they are actually traversing the Shadow Plane (via an effect like Shadow Walk) and end up a considerable distance from where they started. After an hour of delving, the party will exit and be up to 50 miles away. If the shadow travel is detecting early, the party can turn around and exit, they will only be about 25 times further away from their starting point then they thought. Furthermore, some of the doors (all securely locked and trapped, feel free to use any of the previous door traps) along the corridors actually lead to other planes. If a party goes through one of these, they wil end up in a normal looking room on another plane. It most likely won't be apparent that they've wandered out of the Prime Material plane until the exit the structure.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Shadow Walk

 

 

Detecting travel in the plane of Shadow

Hard Spellcraft or Knowledge Planes check.

Hard Spellcraft, Arcana or Dungeoneering.

Plane Doors

 

 

To detect trap and open locks

As per separate stats.

Same as PFRPG

To detect plane transport mechanism

Hard Spellcraft or Perception.

Same as PFRPG

To detect that party is now on different plane

Hard Knowledge Planes check.

Hard Arcana check.

item.title: Wind Wall Cubed (CR 4)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A swirling wall of air is before you!

Type: magical; Perception DC 31; Disable Device DC 28

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The corridor has 3 Wind Walls at 20' intervals. They can be dealt with normally. However, the third Wind Wall has a corridor-wide gelatinous cube right behind it. Any creature that forces his way through the Wind Wall will be automatically engulfed by the cube. (PF Bestiary p. 138)

item.title: Potion Miscibility Table (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Vial filled with colored liquid, covering the entire visible spectrum (and even some of the invisible spectrum) are neatly arranged in a glass case on top of a table. They are all stoppered tightly.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

If the disable device is successful, the vials can be manipulated inside of the glass case safely. Otherwise, unstoppered, all of the vials react violently to air and explode. Each potion is actually a random minor potion, that can be used safely if it does not interact with air. Otherwise, it will explode indivudually. There are 5d4 potions in the rack. Exploding vials (6d6 damage, DC 23 Reflex save for half damage); multiple targets (all targets within 30'). Single Exploding Vial (1d3 damage, DC 17 Reflex for half damage)

item.title: Open Door (CR 3)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The doorway leading out of the room stands open.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 24; Disable Device DC 21

Trigger location; Reset repair

Effect

The door is spiked on the inside, and is held open by a taut spring. If the threshold is crossed, the door will slam on the person walking through. Door Attack (2d6+3 damage, DC 18 Reflex Save avoids)

item.title: This Money is Burning a Hole in my Pocket (CR 3)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
You take the handful of coppers as change and thrown them in your coin purse.

Type: magical; Perception DC 27; Disable Device DC 27

Trigger spell; Reset none

Effect

A copper coin has been enchanted such that if it has not been spent after 24 hours of receiving it, it heats up. A person holding it, or carrying it in such a way that it is in close contact with the person will take 3 rounds of damage (1d4, 2d4, 1d4) before it cools down again. If, however, the coin is in a purse with other coins, it wil melt all the coins together in one big blob of metal, but will not damage the owner. The resulting metallic blob is worth 50% of the original value of the coins.

item.title: Pantheon of Gods
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Who doesn't like robbing and desecrating temples? Turns out, the gods don't much care for it. After some successful plundering of a run of the mill temple dedicated to some god no one has heard of or really cares about anymore, the PC's enter a room containing the large idols of several, bad-ass looking gods that no one has ever heard of, but, apparently, should care about. It's up to the party to make amends and sing the praises to the right gods... or else. If they leave the room without appeasing all the gods, they suffer all of the consequences for every non-appeased god. There should be a big sign or something that says something to the effect of "Appease the gods and you may leave". Or not - up to you. God #1 is a god of healing. The PC's must donate a healing item (potion, ring, whatever) to it God #2 is a god of war. The PC's must donate a weapon to it. God #3 is a god of song. Perform check here... God #4 is a god of wine and spirits. The PC's must donate alcohol. God #5 is a god of wealth. The PC's must donate money. God #6 is is a god of knowledge. Knowledge checks here...

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

All Gods

 

 

To determine what must be given

Hard Knowledge Religion

Same as PFRPG

God of Healing (1)

 

 

Donation

A single healing item

Same as PFRPG

Consequence

Hard Fortitude save or take 1d6 damage per APL.

High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or lose 1/2 of maximum healing surges.

God of War (2)

 

 

Donation

A single weapon

Same as PFRPG

Consequence

Hard Fortitude or primary weapon is destroyed.

High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or lose primary weapon or focus.

God of Song (3)

 

 

Donation

High DC Perform check.

Same as PFRPG

Consequence

Hard Will save or become deaf and mute.

High bonus attack vs. Will or become deaf and mute.

God of Wine and Spirits (4)

 

 

Donation

A single alcoholic beverage

Same as PFRPG

Consequence
