High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or take a -2 penalty on all skill checks for 1d6 hours.

God of Wealth (5)

 

 

Donation

100xAPL gold pieces

Same as PFRPG

Consequence

Hard Will save or be compelled to donate all wealth to god.

High bonus attack vs. Will or be compelled to donate all wealth to god.

God of Knowledge (6)

 

 

Donation

APL # of Hard Random Knowledge checks

Same as PFRPG

Consequence

Hard Will save or all Knowledge based skills are unusable for 1d6 hours.

High bonus attack vs. Will or all Knowledge based skills are unusable for 1d6 hours.

item.title: Voice lock (CR 10)
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
Slightly anachronistic, perhaps, but great for a spellcaster worried about other casters breaking into her tower.
This trap consists of a door that requires a password to be spoken into the ear of a nearby statue or non-critter gargoyle to open. The party (or at least the party scout) should have a chance to see it being used and to get the password, but should not have a reason to test the password themselves - leave the door open while the owner is inside so the rogue can see in. The room beyond should ideally be one that one of the casters will want to enter first - perhaps a wizardly lab or even a necromantic one, to give both arcane and divine types a reason to go first.
The catch is that if the password is spoken by someone other than the owner of the tower, not only does the lock fail to open but the person speaking the password into it feels a puff of air on their face from the statue's ear. That character's player must make a DC 21 Fortitude save - if they fail, pass them a note explaining that their character may not speak or make any vocal noise (humming, etc) - their voice has been locked. (See what we did there?) This effect lasts d6*10 minutes.
To be really cruel, you could make it a bardic library - or indicate that a successful DC 25 Performance (acting) or DC 30 Performance (any vocal skill) check to imitate the owner's voice will successfully fool the lock.

item.title: Wrong Dimension Door (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The room beyond seems to be a small cell

Type: magical; Perception DC 29; Disable Device DC 29

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The doorway is actually a dimension door. Once a character walks through the door, he in transported to a small cell with no exits 500 feet below the surface. Dimension Door (Target is teleported to cell, DC 16 Will Save negates)

item.title: When rooms fly trap (CR 12)
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded: Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  What's more fun than having a traps in a room? Why, making the room itself the trap. When the trap is set off, the PCs are slammed to the ground (i.e. prone) and take falling damage as though they had fallen 30' (Reflex for half). A ghastly howling sound comes from outside the room. Standing up initially requires a DC 25 Strength check, but gets easier over a few rounds. 10 rounds after launch, the PCs are suddenly weightless for a round, after which they drift back to the floor (but still feel strangely light). 10 rounds after the weightless round, the room slams into the ground for 1.5 times maximum falling damage (the landing, plus extra damage from the roof landing on the PCs at terminal velocity). It's up to you whether there are windows or open doorways out which the PCs can look to work out what's going on - we're inclined to recommend against it, though. Casting feather fall inside the room causes roof damage earlier as the PCs slam into the ceiling; casting it on the room itself requires a skill check to modify the spell on the fly. Note that when the PCs leave the room (assuming they survive) they will almost certainly find it is not in the same place as when they entered. If the PCs do somehow survive, and you're feeling mean, roll some dice, pretend to consult a table and tell them it's landed in an active volcano and molten rock is flooding into the shattered room. But not to worry - it's about to erupt and repeat the effect, only this time with ambient lava... Naturally we assume that you will then tell your players you were kidding. But do feel free to have the new location be interesting.

item.title: Swinging rope trap (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: funtruefreefairgood
item.content:encoded:
This rope, found dangling over a yawning gulf, appears to have been used to swing from one side of the chasm to the other - the length is correct, and it doesn't give when yanked on from the near edge. However, that's because of the angle at which it is being pulled. When the force is directed straight down, a spring-loaded reel suddenly pays out another two metres.
When the rope spools out, characters can make a DC 18 Reflex save to respond in time, and if successful can make a DC 20 Climb check to scramble up the rope high enough to clear the lip of the cleft. If they succeed, they can roll onto the far ledge; if they fail by less than 5, they hit the lip and take 1d6 non-lethal damage, but can grab on and pull themselves up (though depending on their Strength and current load, you may require Strength checks for this).
If they fail their Reflex save, they slam into the side of the chasm, dealing 4d6 non-lethal damage and (assuming the victim is still conscious) forcing a Fortitude save equal to the damage dealt to hold onto the rope.
If they let go, the rope spools back in to its original length, and they find out what's at the bottom of the cleft (taking falling damage as appropriate); if they hold on, they can climb up the rope to a point where they will no longer hit the opposite wall, but have lost considerable momentum and will need to spend 3 rounds swinging on the rope to build up their speed enough to make the far side.

item.title: Marked Coin (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The chest overflows with gold pieces.

Type: magical; Perception DC 29; Disable Device DC 29

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

One of the coins has been enchanted in such a way that anyone but the original owner that handles it is immediately affected as if a bestow curse has been cast. The cursed person will be unable to spend money until the curse is removed. The curse otherwise acts the bestow curse spell. Curse (bestows curse, DC 16 Will negates)

item.title: Web of Traps
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Do you know how much effort a nice web takes to set up, only to have it hacked or burned away? Well, this should put a stop to that. The large room is completely filled with a dense web. Every 20', a flask has been suspended in the web. If the web in the 5' area holding the flask is destroyed or disturbed, it will fall and break. If the web is set on fire, the flask will also fall and break when the fire reaches the flask's square. Use normal web rules for movement. There are 4 types of flasks in the web, they should be chosen at random 1) Fireball flask - The flask explodes in a blaze of fire 2) Poison flask - The flask releases a toxic poison 3) Shrapnel flask - The flask releases shrapnel in all directions 4) Sonic flask - The flask releases a loud noise

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Flask

 

 

To detect flask

<= 5 ft Moderate Perception Check

6-20 ft Hard to Very Hard Perception Check

> 20 ft Not detectable

Same as PFRPG

To cause a flask to fall by moving

Any check made to move through the web that fails by 5 or more will cause any flasks in the square being moved out of or into to fall.

Same as PFRPG

Fireball flask (1)

 

 

Attack

A 20' radius blast of fire that causes APL d6 damage and destroys all web. Hard Reflex Save for half damage.

Close Burst 3 High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex for APL d6 damage. All webs in burst are destroyed.

Poison flask (2)

 

 

Attack

A 20' radius blast of poison gas. Damage should be APL/2 Con Damage. Hard Fortitude Save negates.

Close Burst 3 High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude. Damage should be ongoing 5 poison (save ends) per tier plus weakened (save ends).

Shrapnel flask (3)

 

 

Attack

A 20' radius blast of shrapnel. Damage should be APL d6 + APL bleed damage. Hard Reflex Save for half damage and negates bleed.

Close Burst 3 High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex for APL d6 damage and ongoing 5 bleed damage (save ends) per tier.

Sonic flask (4)

 

 

Attack

A 20' radius sonic blast. Damage should be APL d6 and deafened. Hard Fortitude save for half damage and no deafness.

Close Burst 3 High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude for APL d6 damage and deafened (save ends) plus knocked prone.

item.title: Camouflaged Bars (CR 1)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The pickpocket seems to have stolen your coin purse! He's running down the street now and has just ducked down a stairway.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 10

Trigger location; Reset auto

Effect

A metal bar has been placed across the top part of the stairway, and painted to make it hard to see. Bar attack (+10 melee, 1d6 non-lethal damage, 18-20 crit range, crit knocks PC unconscious)

item.title: Pipe Dream (CR 7)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
This parlor is appointed with several plush chairs, and an expensive, carved pipe rack filled with a dozen uniquely crafted pipes.

Type: magical; Perception DC 31; Disable Device DC 31

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

If any of the pipes or paraphernalia (tobacco, matches, etc) are touched, the trap is sprung. The twelve pipes animate and attack. Pipe Attack (+3 melee, 1d6+1 dmg + 1d6 fire damage, AC 16, touch 12, flat-footed 14, 6 HP, Fort +0, Ref +0, Will -1, Hardness 5, Fly 30', Construct traits)

item.title: Fake Spellbook (CR 9)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The outside of this spellbook is covered in arcane runes.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 25; Disable Device DC 25

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

When opened, this fake spellbook shoots several small poisoned needles towards the reader. Poison Needles (DC 27 Reflex save avoids, 1d2 damage, Deathblade poison, 1/round for 6 rounds, 1d3 Con damage, Cure 2 consecutive saves, DC 20 Fortitude save)

item.title: Halfling Floor Tiles (CR 2)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The entryway is tiled and has a low ceiling.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 27; Disable Device DC 21

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

Several of the tiles in the middle of the room are fragile and cover a 10' pit. If any character(s) with a combined weight of 100 lbs or more occupy the same space at any time, the tiles will collapse, dropping the character into the pit. Pit Attack (1d6 damage, DC 17 Reflex avoids)

item.title: Deadly Halfling Floor (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The entryway is carpeted with plush wall to wall carpet and has a low ceiling.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 28; Disable Device DC 22

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The floor under the center of the carpet is weak. If any character(s) weighing more than 100 lbs occupy the same square the carpet will collapse into a pit. When it collapses, it becomes soaked with oil, and sparks ignite the rug. Rug collapse (1d6 damage and character is restrained, DC 19 Reflex avoids, once restrained, the character must escape vs. an 18 CMD to escape). Flaming rug (2d6 damage per turn for all characters in area with the rug, characters restrained by rug take 3d6 damage per turn)

item.title: Electric Rungs (CR 4)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Metal rungs have been inset into the side of the tube, allowing a way to climb down.

Type: magical; Perception DC 28; Disable Device DC 28

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

About halfway down, the rungs become electrified. Electrified rungs (3d6 electric damage or 4d6 falling damage, DC 16 Reflex to avoid electricity damage and fall instead); multiple targets (all targets on rungs)

item.title: Conveyor Columns
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap takes a standard element of dungeon fare and turns it into something deadly. Hopefully, your players will then spend much wasted time examining every column they run across from now on. The party enters a long hall with 2 rows of stone columns supporting a high, arched ceiling. Each pair of columns has about 20 feet of space between them, and the pairs are separated by about 40 feet. When the characters are between a set of columns, it will trigger the trap. A spinning, invisible force field will first crush the characters, then shoot them towards the next set of columns, where the process will repeat until they've gone through all the columns. At the end the characters will be accelerated through a grated doorway.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Column

 

 

To detect forcefield

Very Hard Perception check.

Same as PFRPG

To disable forcefield

Very Hard Disable Devices check.

Very Hard Thievery check.

Rotating forcefield

1d6 per APL crush damage, + 1d4 per APL damage when fired into next set of columns. Initial column gets a Hard Reflex save to avoid.

1d6 per APL crush damage plus 1d4 per APL damage when fired into next set of columns. Initial column is high bonus attack vs. Reflex.

Grated Doorway

 

 

To open

Hard Disable Device check, or destroy as per iron door stats.

Hard Thievery check, or destroy as per iron door stats.

Damage from attack

High bonus melee attack for 2d6 per APL damage plus APL bleed damage. A miss causes half damage and no bleed damage.

High bonus attack vs. AC for 2d6 per APL plus ongoing 5 bleed damage (save ends) per tier. A miss causes half damage with no ongoing damage.

item.title: Brick Wall (CR 2)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
There is a ledge 30 feet up. The irregularly shaped brick wall seems like it can be scaled.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 22; Disable Device DC 18

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

About halfway up, one of the bricks has been spring loaded. If grabbed, it will shoot out. Spring loaded brick (2d6 falling damage, DC 18 Reflex negates falling)

item.title: Sticky Lock (CR 1)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The door is locked, looks like it will have to be picked. Rogue!

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 24; Disable Device DC 24

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

When the lock is picked the trap triggers, filling the lock with a special sovereign glue compound that sets instantly, glueing the tools in place inside of the lock. Only universal solvent can undo this. It also hopelessly jams the locking mechanism.

item.title: Razor Web (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
The hallway ahead is filled with webs.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 28; Disable Device DC 21

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The web strands are razor sharp, and will do damage even if touched. Touch (1d6 damage +1 bleed, DC 18 Reflex negates); If a PC moves through them, they do even more damage. Move (3d6 damage, +11 touch attack); multiple targets (all targets moving through web). In all other aspects, the web acts as per the spell)

item.title: Wax On, Get Waxed Off (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
On the far side of the chasm lies a bound iron door, inset into a large alcove. It looks like you could easily jump the distance.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 31; Disable Device DC 21

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The door on the far side is a locked iron door with several spikes on the outside (DC 28 Perception check). The landing is coated in wax. (DC 31 Perception) Characters can jump across the chasm (it is 10' across) quite easily. However, the landing is sloped towards the door (DC 28 Dungeoneering check), so any characters that jump will be subject to sliding into the spiked door. Slide into spiked door (2d6 damage, DC 18 Reflex save negates)

item.title: Serrated Wall (CR 4)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Several spikes have been inset into the ground at the base of this wall.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 35; Disable Device DC 20

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The top of this 30' wall is finely serrated. Grabbing the top of the wall can cause the character to fall if he free climbs the wall. If a rope is used, when the character is near the top, the rope will break, causing the character to fall. The fall lands on top of the spikes. Serrated attack (3d6 falling damage + 6 bleed damage, DC 20 Reflex negates); multiple targets (all targets on rope or reaching for top).

item.title: Golden Duck Statue (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
A life size replica of a duck, made from pure gold sits on a pedestal.

Type: magical; Perception DC 30; Disable Device DC 30

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

item.title: Don't Take My Spellbook!
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  It takes years of research, adventuring and effort to fill a spellbook. Why should some nosy noon wizard benefit from your villain's hard work? The room that this spellbook is in has been trapped in a nasty way. If the spellbook is opened without the proper command word, the trap is sprung. Each spell in the spellbook becomes the disarm for a corresponding spell trap in the room. If any character leaves the room, every spell trap that has not been disarmed will go off. Each trap has been set with a spell of the same level as the spell it "guards" in the spellbook. To disarm the trap, you have to cast the spell directly from the spellbook, erasing it, and potentially taking any effects. Furthermore, if the casting fails, the trap being disarmed immediately goes off. "Friendly" spells, such as buffs or other beneficial spells either are not trapped, or use the reversible form to cause harm.

D&D 4e:

Spellbook

Same as Spell in Spellbook.

Same as Ritual in Spellbook.

Caster Level is minimum CL to cast spell. Target of spell will match target type of spell in Spellbook.

Same as PFRPG.

item.title: Feast of the Damned
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This is a tribute to the Thanksgiving ritual of cooking a big-ass dinner. The only difference is that there are zombies. The party enters a large kitchen that is adjacent to a large dining room. In the kitchen are several pots and pans, ingredients, dishes and a cookbook. Soon after entering, the zombies will enter the dining area. After a few rounds, they will begin to attack if they are not served. The entire dinner menu must be prepared and served in order to make the zombies disappear. The number of courses is up to you. Until the zombies are fed, though, they keep coming, and there is no way out until they are fed.

item.title: Statuary of Golems
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Some poor sod worked months or even years creating these beautiful statues, only to have your adventurers avoid them, or even worse, deface or destroy them. Add that to pigeons, and it is just too much. Of course, the poor sod who made the statues was probably killed instead of paid anyway... The statues are each made from a different substance and are exquisite and beautiful. They have been placed aside a curvy garden path in various poses. Once someone passes a statue, they will be turned to the same substance as the original statue. The original statue then becomes a golem, and will attack the party. There are six statues, with the golems in increasing order of difficulty. For added fun, there can be some slippery/trapped bridges over running water, leaf covered pits, loose stones in the pathway, or anything else to make the journey just a little more harrowing. For added fun, if the statues are not defeated or the traps disarmed, all the golems come to life at once when the party reaches the exit, which, of course, should be inaccessible until the golems are defeated - perhaps one of them has a key stored away safely in its interior.

item.title: Cave Camp Fire (CR 11)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
This cave seems the perfect place to make camp. It's easily defensible, there are mushrooms growing in the corners for fuel, and the middle is even sunk a little to make a perfect fire pit, even if it is a bit cold in here.

Type: mechanical; Perception DC 31; Disable Device -

Trigger location; Reset none

Effect

The ceiling is actually made of ice. Above the ice is a huge lake of water. If the party makes a campfire, the heat from the campfire will eventually start melting the ceiling. After 1d4+2 hours, the ceiling will collapse, pouring thousands of gallons of water into the cave, effectively flooding the cave. The characters, with a DC 31 Perception check, may notice that water is dripping from the ceiling, and that it wasn't dripping before. Collapsing Ceiling Attack (10d6 damage, DC 28 Reflex for half damage); multiple targets (all targets in cave); Once flooded, drowning rules come into effect, the entire cave complex is flooded and the characters must either exit or get above the level of the bottom of the lake.

item.title: The Sawmill
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  This trap is simply being made because I can. Sawmills have lots of cool stuff that can be potentially deadly, and that's really all I want in a trap. Lots of deadly. The floor of the room they enter is made up of many logs, parallel to the entrance and at a slight incline towards the far side of the room. The logs freely rotate and have a little space in between them. Once the characters have started to traverse the room, trying to keep balance on the logs, saw blades emerge from the floor, travelling back and forth between the logs. Every now and then a plank will enter the room from holes in the entrance wall. When the saw blades cut the planks, it will shoot pieces and wood and create sawdust. Once the characters reach the far side of the room, opening the door will create a spark which will ignite the by-now heavily sawdust-laden air. Oh, one more thing. At the base of the incline there is also a huge, wood-chipper, shredder type device. I imagine going into it would be bad. Good times.

D&D 4e:

To detect trap

Hard Reflex Save or fall prone. Very Hard Reflex Save to stand up. If prone, move 5' toward the Shredder per turn.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex.  Damage should per ongoing 5 bleed damage per tier.

item.title: The Big Wall
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  There's a picture inside of the 4th Edition Player's Handbook that shows an elf disarming a huge wall of (presumably) traps. I believe it is the picture for the Skills chapter. Anyway, this gave me an idea... The room has a giant wall filled with knobs, gears, keyholes, etc on the far side. In the middle is a very vaulty looking door, complete with a rotating handle. Presumably, the party will check for traps, try to disable things, pick locks, etc. This is all fine and good. There are lots of locks to pick and traps to disarm. Your party should be pretty proud of itself by the time it disarms/opens the last device. The trick here, though, is that this isn't designed to keep people out. It's actually a weapon that was designed to be difficult to arm and set off. The entire complex has had delayed blast fireballs embedded in the walls during construction. Once the vault is opened, and the last "trap" disabled, the fireballs explode. Each room has 2-4 fireballs in the wall. The complex is also effective destroyed after the explosion(s).

item.title: Splat Trap
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Remember the splat books from 2nd edition? Well, this is nothing like that. The heroes enter a circular room. The center of the room contains a huge, circular stone tile. 3 foot wide round holes are regularly  spaced out on the walls. The edges of the holes have tiny spikes, which are dripping with some kind of fluid. When the trap is set off, several holes appear in the floor, sucking the characters down. They are whooshed out the holes on the side of the room, where they get slightly gored by the spikes and coated with the liquid. All the characters meet with a "splat" in the middle of the room, on the circular tile, where the liquid mixes and creates a fireball. The fireball then sets off the last trap, a solid stone column falls from the ceiling to squash everyone. Good fun.

Very Hard Perception check

item.title: Abandoned Smithy (CR 5)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:

An odorless, colorless gas seeps into the air from below the ground. It takes quite some time to ignite, but once it does, it is hard to put out. It will also only ignite if fumes from the furnace or sparks from the grinders are also mixed in the air. If the equipment in here is used, the gas will ignite in 10 rounds. Gas Attack (1d6 damage, DC 20 Fortitude save negates, continues to burn for 1d8 rounds for an additional 1d6 damage each round or until save succeeds); multiple targets (all targets in smithy)

item.title: PC vs. Food
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  What can I say, I watch the Travel channel. The characters wander into a large feasting hall, with a table full of food, divided into sections. If they try to leave the room, they notice that the doors have been sealed with what appears to be some kind of wall of force. The only way out is to finish the three eating challenges that present themselves. The first challenge is simple, simply eat the plate of hot wings. The second is to eat a tray of what looks like sliced ham. The third challenge is a huge steak, which must be eaten. Each dish also has some other factors, which can help or hinder. There is also a loaf of bread, a pitcher of milk and a bowl of red sauce and a bowl of white sauce on the table.

item.title: Bloodsmoke (CR 5)

item.title: No Alignment Door (CR 6)

item.title: Phasing Building
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was watching ST:TNG the other day. It inspired this. The characters are wandering through the 2nd story or higher of some building. At some point, the walls and floor shimmer a bit. While they are exploring, the walls and floors should quickly go in and out of phase. The walls also move when they phase, too.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Floor, Stairs or Elevator

 

 

Phasing

Randomly - should be a 1d6 chance every round that floor phases.

same as PFRPG

Phase Effect

Hard Reflex save to avoid falling. If caught in floor, target takes 1d3 Con damage every round till freed.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex or target is caught in floor. If caught in floor, target takes 1d3 Con damage every round until freed.

Freeing

If the floor phases again while caught, target falls and takes appropriate damage. Otherwise, only dimensional travel type spells, like Dimension Door, will free the target.

same as PFRPG, but teleport-like abilities will work, too.

Walls

 

 

Phasing

Randomly - should be a 1 in 10 chance that walls phase (and relocate) every round.

same as PFRPG

Phase Effect

Same as for the floor, except of course, that the target doesn't fall.

same as PFRPG

Freeing

Same as for the floor, except of course, that the target doesn't fall. However, there is again a chance that when the walls relocate, the target is again within the wall. This allows a 2nd save to avoid getting stuck in the wall.

same as PFRPG

item.title: Don't Stay Behind (CR 6)
item.dc:creator: pfworks

item.title: Cooking Pot (CR 11)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Sludge, Clouds and Charge
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Some of my players were trudging through sewers the other day. They were making their way through sludge and all kinds of stuff. So many possibilities... The players walk into a large room, or a high-ceilinged passageway, perhaps even underground. They notice a fog has formed up above, and at the far end of the room is an opening, spilling sludge into the room. The sludge slowly moves, and seems to exit near the entrance, creating a slow moving stream. There are also several corroded metal blocks placed along the room. It looks like you could cross the room by hopping from one block to another. The sludge is corrosive, and if the far end is blocked, the room will empty out. However, once the stream stops, the fog descends into the room, and acts like a Cloudkill or similar spell. The blocks themselves are made out of copper. If the stream is moving, it creates a charge that is discharged should someone make contact with the block. For fun, the door can seal behind them when they arrive.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Blocks

 

 

To climb atop

Easy Climb check.

Easy Athletics check

To jump from one block to another

Moderate Jump check or fall in sludge

Moderate Athletics check

Charged Attack

Hard Reflex save or take APL*d6 points of electricity damage

High bonus attack vs. Reflex or take APL*d6 points of electricity damage

Sludge

 

 

To block opening

Moderate Dungeoneering check

same as PFRPG

Sludge Effect

Hard Fortitude or take APL*d6 points of acid damage each round.

Acts as an aura. Each round take ongoing 5 poison damage. (save ends)

Fog

 

 

To negate fog

Any wind effect will dissipate fog. 

same as PFRPG

Fog damage

 As Cloudkill with DC 17 save.

Acts as an aura. Each round take ongoing 10 poison damage.

item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:

item.title: May the Force be in You
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Walls of force are great. But perhaps, pieces of a wall of force, pieces with pointy ends and sharp bits are even better. The characters enter a big room that appears to be empty. There are three different trap areas as they progress through the room. The first part is basically a spiked obstacle of force. The force spikes phase in and out as the characters traverse the area. The second area of the room has falling walls of force. The third section has force floors, transparent that cover spiked pits. The floors phase in and out.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Spikes

 

 

To detect spikes

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Spike Attack

50% chance that spikes are present. Very Hard Reflex save or take 1d6 * APL damage per round while in same space as spikes.

4 5 6 recharge. Very High Bonus attack vs. Reflex for 1d6 * APL damage plus target is slowed.

Walls

 

 

To detect walls

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Wall Attack

50% chance that wall falls. Hard Reflex Save or take 2d6 * APL damage and target is pinned.

4 5 6 recharge. High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex for 2d6 * APL damage, plus target is immobilzed (save ends) and stunned (save ends)

Floor

 

 

To detect floor phase

Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Floor attack

 50% chance that floor disappears. High Reflex save or fall into pit for 1d6 + 6 damage. Then 50% chance that floor appears again, trapping character.

50% chance that floor disapperas. High Bonus attack vs. Reflex or character falls into pit for 1d6 + ongoing 5 bleed damage. (save ends). Then 50% chance that floor appears, trapping character.

item.title: The Elements
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  My friend was baking the other day, and accidentally burnt herself with the baking pan. This got me thinking about burns, heat, cold, etc. The characters enter a long, wide hallway. About every 30'-40' there is a statue. When the characters get within about 10' of a statue, it activates a trap. There are a total of 6 statues. The statues must be deactivated to pass and clear up the trap effects. 1) Steam 2) Ice 3) Lava 4) Liquid 5) Flame 6) Cold

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Steam

 

 

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Steam Attack

Steam jets shoot up from the floor creating 2 attacks. Jet Attack (Very Hard Reflex save to avoid; damage should be about 1d6 per APL) Steam Cloud (Hard Fortitude Save or take 1d6 per APL, steam cloud attacks each round until statue deactivated)

Steam jets shoot from floor creating 2 attacks. Jet Attack (4,5,6 recharge, High Bonus Reflex Attack for 1d6 per APL damage) Steam Cloud (ongoing 5 heat damage per tier (save ends))

Deactivating Statue

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. The steam provides a +2 to the statue's AC. The statue will attack if attacked or if someone attempts to pass.

same as PFRPG

Ice

 

 

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Ice Attack

All characters caught in a flurry of ice. High bonus attack vs. AC or take 1d6 per APL damage each round. Also, floor becomes icy. DC 10 balance check each round or character becomes prone.

Flurry of ice. 4,5,6 recharge. High bonus attack vs. AC. Damage should be about 1d6 per APL. Treat area as difficult terrain.

Deactivating Statue

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. The ice gives the statue DR/2 physical.

same as PFRPG.

Lava

 

 

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Lava Attack

Lava Bursts. Hard Reflex save to avoid. Damage should be about 2d6 per APL. Exposed flammable items have a 25% chance of catching fire.

Lava Bursts. 4,5,6 recharge. High bonus attack vs. Reflex. Damage should be about 2d6 per APL. Ongoing 5 per tier fire damage (save ends) on hit.

Deactivating Statue

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. Lava gives statue +2 to damage.

same as PFRPG.

Liquid

 

 

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Liquid Attack

Entire area doused in a super-cooled liquid. Hard Fortitude save or take 1d6 per APL cold damage, plus 1d4 damage per round.

Entire area doused in a super-cooled liquid. High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or take 1d6 per APL cold damage plus ongoing 5 cold damage. (save ends)

Deactivating Statue

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. Physical weapons and armor, if not heated first, must make a Hard Fortitude save the first time they strike/are struck or they will shatter.

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. Characters must be heated by some means or are weakened.

Flame

 

 

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Flame Attack

Flame Jets from statue. Hard Reflex save or take 2d6 per APL damage. Flammable objects have a 50% chance of catching on fire.

Flame Jets from status. High bonus attack vs. Reflex or take 2d6 per APL damage plus ongoing 10 fire damage (save ends)

Deactivating Statue

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. The statue also can use the flame jet attack as a standard action.

same as for PFRPG.

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

The ambient temperature instantly drops. Exposed characters must make a Hard Fortitude save or take 1d6 damage per round. Characters in medium or heavy armor lose Dex bonus to AC. Spell casters must make a DC 15 Concentration check to cast somatic spells.

The ambient temperature instantly drops dealing ongoing 10 cold damage (save ends). Characters in medium or heavy armor lose Dex bonus to AC. High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or lose a healing surge. Characters gain Vulnerability 5/ cold.

Treat statue as an appropriately leveled construct. Attacks from construct are +2 and deal cold damage.

same as PFRPG

item.title: Standard Door Opening Formation
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  My players have a standard door opening formation at times. The rogue is in front of the door, some stand back and other stand off to the side. This is dull. This needs fixing. Plus, as anyone who reads this blog knows, I hate doors, or, more to the point, my doors hate players. This trap has three areas. Area 1 is the area beside the door and near the walls, out to 10'. Area 2 is the area 10' out from the door and walls. Area 3 is the door itself. When the door is opened, the walls collapse onto area 1, which in turn collapses the floor and drops the characters into spiked pits. The floors in area 2 tilt, catapulting the characters into hooks in the ceiling, which then break, dropping them into the spiked and barbed pits in area 1, along with half the ceiling. The poor guy opening the door sets off a heavy gas trap. The gas settles into the pits in area 1. Additionally, his hand is glued to the door, so he gets to watch his party slowly die. All in all, good fun, and the door still isn't open, although without any walls...

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Area 1 (wall)

 

 

Wall Collapse

Hard Reflex save or take 1d6 * APL damage and be knocked prone.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex or take 1d6 * APL damage and be knocked prone.

Floor collapse into spiked pits

Very Hard Reflex save or take (1d6 + 1) * APL damage and become entangled with spikes. (Prone characters from above lose Dex bonus to save) Entangled characters may escape with a Hard Escape Artist or against a high CMD with no damage. If they do otherwise, they take APL bleed damage escaping.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex or take (1d6 + 1) * APL damage and become weakened (save ends) and immobilized (save ends) and take ongoing 5 bleed damage (save ends). Remember that prone characters from above lose any Dex bonus to Reflex.

Area 2 (away from door/wall)

 

 

Catapult into Hooks

Very Hard Reflex Save or be catapulted into hooks on ceiling for 1d6 * APL damage and character is immobilized. 1d4 rounds later, the hooks break and take the ceiling with it. Very High Escape Artist check or CMD to escape hooks before falling.

Very High bonus attack vs. Reflex or be catapulted into hooks for 1d6 * APL damage and become immobilized (save ends) and take ongoing 5 bleed damage (save ends). 1d2 round later, hooks break and take ceiling with it.

Hooks Breaking and falling into pit.

Characters take 2d6 falling damage and APL spike damage. See escape conditions above.

same as PFRPG.

Falling Ceiling

Hard Reflex save if not immobilized or take 1d6 * APL damage and become shaken for 1d6 rounds.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex if not immobilized or take 1d6 * APL damage and become dazed. (save ends)

Area 3 (door)

 

 

To detect trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Glue Trap

Very Hard Fortitude save or become immobilized with one hand stuck on the door. Any assistance to characters will be at a -8 penalty. Must use spell or item to free oneself, or can rip oneself free in 1d6 rounds and suffer 1d2 Dex loss and 1d2 Con loss.

Very High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or become immobilized with one hand stuck to door. Any assistance to other characters will be at a -8 penalty. Must use spell, item or ritual to free oneself, or can rip oneself free in 1d6 rounds and take ongoing 15 bleed damage (save ends)

Gas (in pits)

Hard Fortitude save or take 1d6 Con damage and become nauseated until 2 consecutive saves are made.

High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or take ongoing 10 poison damage (save ends) and become  stunned (save ends)

item.title: Moving Pits
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was trying to come up with a trap that reminded me of one of this little sliding tile puzzle games, and here it is. The characters get dropped (by some mechanism) into a large room. The floor and 4 walls are tiled with big tiles (5'x5') and each wall has one tile missing. Instead of a tile, there is nothing but darkness. They have to get the blank tile in the same spot on all 4 walls and the floor. The trick is, every time they move a tile, and create a new spot for the pit that matches no other pit, a random result will happen. You can go to the effort of actually making 5 walls and having the characters move stuff around, or, you can make this a puzzle/skill challenge and require something like 10 successes in 20 attempts to finish the challenge, with Bad Stuff(TM) happening on each failure.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Floor

 

 

To correctly move tile

Hard Intelligence check

same as PFRPG

Failure

Very Hard Will save or character takes 1d3 Int damage.

To correctly move tile

Hard Wisdom check

same as PFRPG

Failure

Very Hard Will save or character is drained 1 level.

Very High bonus attack vs. Will or character is drained 1 level.

South Wall

 

 

To correctly move tile

Hard Athletics check.

Same as PFRPG

Failure

Very Hard Fortitude save or character becomes exhausted.

High bonus attack vs. Fortitude or character becomes weakened. (save ends)

West Wall

 

 

To correctly move tile

Hard Knowledge Arcana check.

Same as PFRPG

Failure

Very Hard Reflex save for entire party or each character takes APL * 6 electrical damage.

To correctly move tile

Same as PFRPG

Failure

item.title: Death Spiral Stairs
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  What's more fun than a set of spiral stairs in a dungeon? How about a set that can take out the entire party? The party is ambling along and reaches a downward set of spiral stairs with long drop offs on the outside, and a narrow drop off down the middle. A very long carpet runner runs the length of the stairs. The stairs have several traps, all designed to enhance the stair descending experience. Once found, all traps can be easily avoided or disarmed, except for trap 5. Trap 5 can be easily avoided but will be Very Hard to disarm. Trap 1: The top several stairs are spring-loaded, and will hurl the target off the outside or inside if set off. The outside is simply a long fall. The inside is a long fall down a narrowing cylinder. The cylinder also has downward pointing spikes, which will make extraction... interesting. Trap 2: Further down, some of the stairs are very fragile. Breaking them releases a poison gas. Trap 3: Even further down, a couple of the stairs are illusions. Stepping on them will cause the target to fall. Trap 4: A step causes the runner to roll up, starting at the top. Trapped characters will be taken all the way to the bottom, where the runner will crash into a wall and then be set afire. Trap 5: The very last stair causes the entire stairway to vanish, plunging characters on the stair all the way to the ground.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Trap 1

 

 

To detect the trap

Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Flung to the outside (50% chance)

Moderate Reflex save or take falling damage which should be about 30ft * APL.

Moderate bonus attack vs. Reflex or take falling damage, which should be about 30ft * APL.

Flung to the inside (50% chance)

Hard Reflex save or take falling damage which should be about 10ft * APL. Extraction requires extremely hard Escape Artist check or take an additional 1d10 * APL bleed damage per 10ft.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex or take falling damage of about 10ft * APL. Extraction requires extremely hard Acrobatics check or take 1d6 * APL damage per 10ft plus ongoing 5 bleed damage per tier.

To detect the trap

Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Gas covers entire stairway from this point to the top. Treat as if entire area is affected by a Cloudkill cast at CL 9 or APL, whichever is greater.

To detect the trap

Hard Perception check.

Falling

To detect the trap

Same as PFRPG

item.title: Jellyfish Pool (CR 1)
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:

item.title: The Spinner
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was thinking of how flour is made, which caused me to think of how characters are unmade. The party sees an irregularly shaped room in front of them The side walls are convex and made of stone, and the front and back walls are smooth and black. The floor is also made of stone. All the stonework appears to be absolutely smooth and flawless, with no seams, cracks or imperfections. The middle of the floor is a round stone that seamlessly fits into the floor and rotates at an extremely high speed. The side, convex walls also rotate at an opposite rotation of the floor. The back and front walls are made of a smooth, rubbery substance. Lastly, there are columns that fall from the ceiling and pin characters to the floor. The trap is sprung when a character gets about halfway across the room. The columns drop, randomly pinning characters in place and the floor spins. Those caught under the columns are ground. Those not caught are flung into the side walls, ground a bit, and then flung into the back or front wall where they are bounced back into the rotating disk to start all over again.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Columns

 

 

To detect the trap

Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Column Attack

Moderate bonus attack vs. CMD or become pinned. Escape is possible via Hard Escape Artist or CMB vs. High CMD.

Moderate bonus attack vs. Reflex or become restrained. (save ends)

Disk Attack

If pinned, take 1d6 per APL bleed damage each round. If not pinned, Hard Reflex save or be flung into side walls. Successful save flings character off of disk in a random direction for 1d4 per APL damage.

If restrained, take ongoing 5 per tier bleed damage. If not restrained, High Bonus attack vs. Reflex or be flung into side walls. On a successful save, character is pushed to a random square in the room off of the disk.

Side Disk Walls

 

 

To detect the trap

Hard Perception check to detect walls are spinning

same as PFRPG

Wall Attack

High bonus attack vs. AC or take 1d6 bleed damage per APL. High bonus attack vs. CMD or be flung into back or front walls. Missed CMD attack causes character to be prone in front of the spinning side wall.

High bonus attack vs. AC or take ongoing 5 per tier bleed damage. High bonus attack vs. Reflex or be flung into back or front wall. Missed attack vs. Reflex causes character to be pushed to a random square near spinning disk wall.

Rubber Walls

 

 

To identify wall

Moderate Dungeonerring check

Same as PFRPG

Falling

Very Hard Reflex save or be flung into spinning disk floor, and repeat disk floor attack. On a miss, character is prone near wall.

High bonus attack vs. Reflex or be flung into spinning disk floor, and repeat disk floor attack. On a miss, character is prone near wall.

item.title: Lend a Hand
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was doing some door traps (shocker) and was using some of the various "Hand" spells. It gave me an idea... There are a lot of spells in the CRB based on the old Bigby's hand spells. Why not meet all of them? The first trap consists of a small spectral hand that delivers a shocking grasp spell. It is protected by an Interposing Hand. The party then encounters a deep chasm, crossed with a narrow bridge. Once on the bridge, they are bull rushed by a Forceful Hand. The party then sets off a fire trap, bathing an area in flame. At the same time, each member is attacked by a Grasping Hand, that keeps the characters in place, in the flames. After leaving the flames, a random party member is attacked by a Clenched Fist. Finally, the party reaches the door on the far side of the chamber, where the first one to open the door is hit with a Crushing Hand. All hands attack until destroyed. They are AC (17 + APL) with (10* APL) HP. Magic, unless it does damage, does not affect them. For Pathfinder, the complete stats can be found under the Interposing Hand spell.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Interposing Hand

 

 

Hand Effect

The hand interposes itself between you and the attacking spectral hand, giving the spectral hand a +4 bonus to AC.

same as PFRPG

Trap Effect

Spectral Hand (AC 10 + APL, HP APL). Delivers a shocking grasp-like effect. High bonus ranged touch for APL/2 * d6 electrical damage. If destroyed, regenerates until interposing hand is destroyed.

same as PFRPG

Forceful Hand

 

 

Hand Effect

Bull Rush to knock character off of bridge into deep chasm (20' * APL deep). CMB should be about 11 + APL. 

High bonus Bull Rush attack to push character off of bridge.

Trap Effect

Chasm should be about 20' * APL deep.

same as PFRPG

Grasping Hand

 

 

Hand Effect

Grapple attempt to immobilize character. CMB should be about 11 + APL. and CMD should be about 21 + APL.

High bonus grab attack to Immobilize character.

Trap Effect

Flames appear around each character. They should do about 1d6 * APL damage per round while immobilized.

Ongoing 5 per tier fire damage while immobilized.

Clenched Fist

 

 

Hand Effect

Hand strikes character. Melee attack of 15 + APL for 1d8 + APL damage. DC (14 + APL) Fortitude save on successful hit or be stunned for 1 round.

High bonus attack vs. AC or take 1d8 + APL damage and become stunned. (save ends)

Crushing Hand

 

 

Hand Effect

Hand grapples character. CMB should be about 13 + APL for 2d6 + APL damage. Character is immobilized while grappled.

Very High bonus attack vs. AC or take 2d6 + APL damage and become immobilized. (save ends)

item.title: Falling Down
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  In my workout today, there were a whole lot of fall down, get up, type exercises today. This gave me an idea... The characters are presented with a long hallway. At several points along the hallway, traps are triggered that are designed to knock the characters down, and sometimes, do nasty stuff while they are on the ground. Trap 1: Acid jets shoot out at about ankle high Trap 2: Saw Blades pop up through the floor Trap 3: A tripwire has been placed on the floor. Above it, is an invisible spike hanging from the ceiling Trap 4: The floor has turned to gravel. A big stick swings out at head level. When the character ducks, the resulting motion causes the gravel to spark, setting off some gas at floor level that was just released.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Acid Jets

 

 

To detect trap

Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Trap Effect

High bonus attack vs. Reflex for 1d6 * APL damage plus be knocked prone.

Saw Blades

 

 

To detect trap

Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Trap Effect

Hard Reflex save for all characters within 20' of trap or take 1d6 * APL + APL bleed damage and be knocked prone.

High bonus burst 2 attack vs. Reflex for 1d6 * APL damage plus take ongoing 5 per tier bleed damage, be knocked prone and immobilized. (save ends)

Tripwire/Spike

 

 

To detect trap

Easy Perception check to spot tripwire, Very Hard Perception check to spot spike.

same as PFRPG

Trap Effect

Tripwire disables the spike. If jumped or stepped over, spike attacks head. High bonus attack vs. AC for 2d6 * APL damage. Character must also make a DC 13 + APL Fortitude save or be knocked unconscious for 1d4 rounds.

Tripwire disables the spike. If jumped or stepped over, spike attacks head. High bonus attack vs. AC for 2d6 * APL damage, plus character is knocked unconscious. (save ends)

same as PFRPG

item.title: Rogue Test
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  What does your rogue value more, treasure or the party? This trap is designed to find out. The party enters an elaborately decorated study, complete with bookshelves, desks, etc. A small painting on top of the desk displays an overhead representation of the room. Sitting on the painting are several valuable gems, one for each member of the party. The gems are placed where the characters are, and slowly move when the characters move. An appraise check should show the gems to be worth thousands each. Additionally, each gem is only visible to someone that is actually a rogue or thief. The gems are easily pocketed. Each gem represents a party member, with the exception of the rogue. His gem doesn't do anything. 1d4 rounds after pocketing a gem, the party member that corresponds to the gem begins to suffer one of the random effects below. The gem also warms up for 1d4 rounds after the effect starts. It gets warm enough for the rogue to notice, but not warm enough to do damage. Once afflicted, the symptoms can be managed, but the malady can only be cured by returning the gems.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Gem Effect 1

 

 

Pestilence

Boils begin to appear on the face and neck. Lose 1d2 points of Constitution per day. (can be restored)

same as PFRPG

Gem Effect 2

 

 

Clumsiness

Faint numbness is felt on the extremities. Lose 1d2 points of Dex per day. (can be restored)

same as PFRPG

Gem Effect 3

 

 

Foolishness

The character has a slight headache. Lose 1d2 points of Wisdom per day. (can be restored) 

same as PFRPG

item.title: You Probably Just Want to go Around...
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Sometimes, taking a detour, even if it is long, is the best course of action. The heroes approach a narrow, deep ravine. The other side looks like it is sandy. It's narrow enough that it can probably be jumped over. There is also a log that crosses it, a rope bridge, a swinging rope and what looks like a stone bridge. Should be a piece of cake to cross. However, there are a few gotchas. The sandy ground on the far side is actually quicksand. Anyone jumping over it lands in the quicksand, which isn't really a good thing. The log is merely hollow and rotted and filled with rot grubs. The rope bridge works fine, but the handholds are actually assassin vines. The swinging rope is a venomous snake that looks like rope. The venom doesn't really hurt you though, it just instantly paralyzes you. The stone bridge is a perfectly stable stone bridge, except that the top surface is actually a gray ooze.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Sandy Ground

 

 

Detect

Very Hard Perception or Hard Nature check

same as PFRPG

Effect

If jumped into, character is immediately submerged and subject to drowning rules. Very Hard Strength or Escape Artist to escape. Otherwise, character begins to sink (moderate Strength or Escape Artist) until submerged 2 rounds later.

If jumped into, character is immediately submerged. Ongoing 5 points per tier of Suffocation damage until escaped. Very Hard Athletics or Acrobatics check to escape. Otherwise, character begins to sink (moderate Athletics or Acrobatics) until submerged 2 rounds later.

Log

 

 

Detect

Hard Nature or Very Hard Dungeoneering check.

same as PFRPG

Effect

Each 5', character makes a Hard Acrobatics check or part of the log collapses, releasing rot grubs. Unless healing or fire is applied (1d6 damage), the character will die in 1d4 + 2 rounds.

same as PFRPG

Rope Bridge

 

 

Detect

Hard Nature, Very Hard Dungeoneering or Extremely Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Effect

About halfway across the bridge, the assassin vines will attack, and attempt to throw characters off the bridge if the vines take too much damage.

same as PFRPG

Swinging Rope

 

 

Detect

Hard Nature or Very Hard Perception check.

same as PFRPG

Effect

Once swinging, the snake will attempt to bite the character with a high attack bonus melee attack. If successful, the character must make a Hard Fortitude Save or become paralyzed for 1d2 rounds, falling into the ravine.

Once swinging, the snake will attempt to bite the character with a high attack bonus melee attack. If successful, the poison makes a high attack bonus attack vs. Fortitude. On a hit, the character becomes paralyzed for 1d2 rounds, falling into the ravine.

Stone Bridge

 

 

Detect

Hard Nature or Dungeoneering check; Very Hard Perception check

same as PFRPG

Effect

About halfway across the bridge, the gray ooze will attack. For higher levels, add more oozes.

same as PFRPG

item.content:encoded:

Effect

Once the flash of light has happened, a second perception check can be made to note that the shadows' movement is not quite in sync with the party. Once the shadows attack, each player can make a DC 23 Will save. If made, the shadows have only 20% of the HP of the party members and deal 20% of the damage, otherwise, they have full HP and deal full damage. They also have access to whatever spells the party had when copied. The CR for this trap is the APL.

item.title: Ball of Flame Room
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  Bouncing, burning balls. What could be more fun? The party enters a large room or cavern. The floor is literally covered in small, flaming spheres. There seems to be paths through the spheres, if the party if willing to take a serpentine route. A single party member can cross the room without a problem. However, if 2 or more characters decide to cross the room, they start to set up vibrations. In a few rounds, the vibrations hit resonance and start throwing flaming spheres all over the room.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Room

 

 

To detect safe passage

Easy Perception check or bump into a single sphere. (1d6 fire damage)

same as PFRPG

 

 

Resonance

Very Hard Dungeoneering check to detect subtle vibrations in floor growing. Once 2 or more characters are crossing the room, the spheres will begin to wildly crash about in 1d3 rounds.

same as PFRPG

 

 

Crashing Spheres

Each round, the character is hit by 1d10 spheres (Hard Reflex Save for half that number). Each sphere does 1d6 fire damage.

Each round, each character in room is hit by 1d10 spheres (If high bonus attack vs. Reflex hits. If missed, half that number) for 1d6 damage per sphere plus ongoing 5 fire damage. (does not stack, save ends)

item.title: Stuck Arm Lock (CR 3)

Effect

Scoop Attack (DC 24 Reflex Avoids, otherwise character is trapped against wall); Multiple targets (all targets within 5' of door); Compression Attack (DC 27 Strength Check or Escape Artist to escape, 1d6 Con dmg/round); multiple targets (all targets trapped against wall)

Effect

item.title: Channel Surfing
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was watching some retro 70's sci-fi, and I saw some TV's - you know, the kind where you had to manually turn the dial. It got me thinking. The party enters a chamber. Once they get in the room, the entrance seals shut and the room starts to fill up with water. In the middle of the room is a large wheel that sits atop a closed drain. Each time the wheel is turned a notch, it channels a different type of energy, until it gets to the end and the drain opens. At each position, the channeling is continuous. Once the door and drain are opened, the water drains away.  If you feel like it, add a rotating blade in the drain and have the characters pulled towards it as the water drains. The wheel has six positions: 1) Electricity 2) Negative 3) Sonic 4) Force 5) Air 6) Open drain and door

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Wheel

 

 

To turn wheel

Hard Strength check

Hard Athletics check

Electricity

 

 

Very Hard Fortitude Save (Moderate if not standing in water) or take APL*6 damage

Very High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude (Moderate bonus if not standing in water) or take APL*6 damage

Negative

 

 

Hard Will save or take 1 negative level.

High bonus attack vs. Will or take 1 negative level.

Sonic

 

 

Very Hard Fortitude save or take APL*6 damage and become deafened for APL rounds.

Very High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude or take APL*6 damage and become deafened (save ends)

Force

 

 

Hard Fortitude Save or be pushed back to walls, taking APL*2 damage. 

High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude or take APL*2 damage and be slid all the way to the walls.

Air

 

 

Very Hard Fortitude Save or be knocked prone. Must make a hard Strength or Acrobatics check to stand up. Character will be under water and subject to normal drowning rules.

Very High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude or be knocked prone. Must make a hard Acrobatics or Athletics check to stand up. Character will be under water and subject to normal drowning rules.

item.title: Squirt, Burn and Explode
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  For some reason, I was thinking of those old wine/waterskins and it gave me an idea... The characters ignite a firestorm trap in a hallway or tunnel. When they reach the end, it opens up into a balcony that overlooks a pool, and on the far side is another balcony. It looks like it could be easily jumped. The far balcony sits atop dozens of waterskins, filled with flammable liquid. When it is landed upon, the liquid squirts out towards the flames, causing the whole first balcony to explode in a fireball, dropping any characters still on it into the pool. The pool is also filled with flammable liquid. The resulting splash ignites the pool, which causes another explosion, knocking the far balcony down and dumping them into the flaming pool as well. Good fun.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Fireball

 

 

Moves 20' per round. Moderate Reflex save or take APL*6 damage.

Moves 4 squares per round. Those within fire take ongoing 5 per tier fire damage.

Jump

 

 

Moderate Acrobatics check or fall in pool. Landing sends streams of liquid to balcony, causing the first explosion.

Moderate Athletics check or fall into pool. Landing sends streams of liquid to balcony, causing the first explosion.

First Explosion

 

 

2*APL*6 damage to everyone on first balcony and they are thrown in pool. Hard Reflex save for half damage and stay on balcony. (in the fire)

High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex or take 2*APL*6 damage and be thrown into pool. On a miss take half damage and remain on balcony in the fire.

Second Explosion

 

 

Very Hard Reflex save or take 2*APL*6 damage. While in pool and not submerged, take an additional APL*6 damage per round. Those on the second balcony that fail the Reflex save fall into the pool. Those that succeed take half damage, and are in the fire.

Very High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex or take 2*APL*6 damage. While in pool and not submerged, take ongoing 5 fire damage per round. Those on the second balcony that are hit fall into the pool. Those that are missed stay on the second balcony in the fire and take ongoing 5 fire damage per round in the flames.

item.title: Area Effect Hell
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was having a discussion about minions both in 4e and Pathfinder. We were discussing some of the mechanical differences between the two, such as at higher levels in PF, you can kill more than one minion with your standard attacks, where as in 4e, you have to rely on Encounter or other powers to do so. Well, this got me to thinking about indiscriminate use of AoE as a whole. So, the characters should enter a large space, a cavern, hall, whatever, and run into dozens if not hundreds of orbs, goblins, whatever particular minion suits your fancy. However, the area has been rigged to deliver a nasty effect for about any type of AoE as per below. Sure, the minions will all die, too.

Damage Type (AoE)

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Fire

 

 
The air is extremely flammable and ignites

Hard Reflex Save or take APL*6 fire damage in a 50' radius from target. Successful save takes half damage.

High Bonus Burst 5 Attack from target vs. Reflex for APL*6 damage. Miss takes half damage.

Acid

 

 
The air/ground is saturated with a basic substance, and explodes

Hard Fortitude Save or take APL*6 acid damage in a 50' radius from target. Successful save takes half damage.

High Bonus Burst 5 Attack from target vs. Fortitude for APL*6 damage plus ongoing 5 acid damage.

Cold

 

 
Pockets of superheated air cause steam jets to form

High Bonus Ranged Touch Attack vs. all characters within 50' of target for APL*6 damage.

High Bonus Burst 5 Attack vs. Reflex from target or take APL*6 damage.

Electricity

 

 
The ground and walls are highly conductive

Very Hard Reflex save or take spell damage vs. all characters within 50' of target. On a successful save, effect is same as spell effect.

Very High Bonus Burst 5 Attack vs. Reflex or take spell damage. Miss and ongoing effects are the same as power used.

Sonic

 

 
The walls and floor are shaped to cause resonance and reflection

Hard Fortitude Save or take spell   damage x 2 on all characters within 50' of target. On a successful save, effect is same as spell effect.

High Bonus Burst 5 Attack vs. Fortitude or take Critical Power Damage. Miss and ongoing effects are same as power used.

item.title: Oiled Chute
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was thinking of Tuesday's trap, and I wanted oil involved somehow. By the time I got done thinking, I came up with Thursday's trap... The characters stumble upon a room that has a floor made of rough metal tiles. At some point in the room, a part of the floor collapses, sending the character down a long, oiled chute. However, the chute is made of jagged flint. The metal tiles spark and set the oil on fire. When the character hits the bottom of the chute, he lands in a cushioned wall with spikes protruding between the cushions. However, the cushions bags full of black powder. When the fire burns down to the bottom, they explode, propelling the hapless victim right back out the chute. If the party members are in the chute, or standing if front of the opening, so much the better.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Collapsing Tiles

 

 
Detect

Very Hard Perception Check

same as PFRPG
Effect

Very Hard Reflex save or fall into chute.

High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex or fall into chute.

Chute

 

 
Movement

Slide down 40' per round.

Slide down 4 squares per round.
Effect

Moderate bonus attack vs. flat-footed AC for 1d4 damage per round. Chute is set on fire 1 and lags the sliding character by 5'. Character can stop slide with a Very Hard Acrobatics check.

Moves 4 squares per round. Those within fire take ongoing 5 per tier fire damage.

Spikes

 

 

APL * d6 damage.

same as PFRPG

Explosion

 

 

Near Impossible Reflex for half damage of 2*APL*d6 fire damage.

Absurd Attack Bonus vs. Reflex or take 2*APL*d6 fire damage. Take half damage on miss.

Canon Shot

 

 
Victim

2*APL*d6 impact damage on ceiling, and an additional 1d6 damage as he falls to the floor.

same as PFRPG
Bystanders - In Tube

2*APL*d6 impact damage plus APL*6 impact damage from ceiling plus 1d6 damage falling to the floor.

same as PFRPG
Bystanders - Not In Tube

High Reflex Save or take APL*d6 fire damage.

High Attack Bonus vs. Reflex or take APL*d6 fire damage.

item.title: Changing Maze
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I got nothing today, so, let's go with a simpler one based on a maze. Every 10' segment of wall in this maze rotates. Shortly after passing an opening, a wall will rotate shut, changing the maze and blocking the ways to the exit/entrance. Various spells can be used to assist, but some have side effects. Physical solutions also have side effects.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Dispelling the Magic

 

 

Dispel Magic vs. DC 27. Other spells that would affect the walls treat the above as SR.

Dispel Magic vs Will of 20 + APL. Other spells that would affect the walls use the same number for defense.

Destroying Wall

 

 

Walls are normal dungeon walls with the appropriate hardness. However, when destroyed they explode, causing APL * d6 damage in a 20' radius (Moderate Reflex Save for half damage) and immediately regenerate.

Walls are normal dungeon walls with the appropriate hardness. However, when destroyed they explode, causing APL * d6 damage blast 2 with a Moderate bonus attack vs. Reflex. 

Spiking Wall

 

 

When the wall is spiked, make a Dungeoneering check. The result is the DC that the wall needs to overcome the spike. The wall then gets a bonus of 10 + APL to beat the DC of the spike. If it succeeds, it fires the spike at the party, where it attacks a random party with a high bonus ranged attack for 1d6 damage.

same as PFRPG.

Escaping

 

 

Very Hard Dungeoneering checks. Party must succeed 5 times in a row to escape. Each altered wall gives a +1 circumstance bonus.

Same as PFRPG.

item.title: Ball Bearings
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I don't know why I picked ball bearings. It was an image that just popped into my mind. The party should enter a sloped tunnel. Shortly after entering thousands of ball bearings appear and whisk the characters down the tunnel. First they pass a spot that heats up the ball bearings. Next, they find some temporary relief as the bearings cool off, but then they get really cold. After that they hit a patch of electricity. Finally, they hit a giant magnet in the floor, which should propel them down the shaft into the huge pile of small, spiked ball bearings which will cut them, then crush and suffocate them.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Ball Bearings

 

 

Very Hard Reflex Save or be knocked prone and moved down corridor at 60' per round. An Extremely Hard Acrobatics check is required to stop movement, and a Very Hard Climb check is required to climb back up tunnel.

Very High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex or be knocked prone and pushed 12 squares down the tunnel per round. An Extremely Hard Acrobatics check is required to stop movement, and a Very Hard Climb check is required to climb back up tunnel.

Heat

 

 

High Fortitude Save or take APL * d6 fire damage for APL rounds.

High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude or take ongoing 5 per tier of fire damage for APL rounds. (save ends)

Cold

 

 

High Survival Check or take APL * d6 non-lethal damage for APL rounds.

High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude or take ongoing 5 per tier of cold  damage for APL rounds.

Electricity

 

 

High Reflex Save (with no dex bonus) or take APL * d6 electricity damage for APL rounds.

High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex or take APL * d6 electricity damage  and ongoing 5 fire damage per tier. (save ends)

Spiked Ball Bearings

 

 

High Bonus Attack vs. flat-footed AC or take APL * d4 damage. Each round take APL * d4 crushing damage and character is suffocating. Escape requires a Very Hard Strength or Escape Artist check.

High Bonus Attack vs. AC or take APL * d4 damage. While in pile, take ongoing 5 per tier crushing damage, and character is suffocating. Escape requires a Very Hard Strength or Escape Artist check.

item.title: Nightmare
item.dc:creator: pfworks
item.content:encoded:
Here is another installment of exTRAPaganza, our Thursday over-the-top trap series.  I was doing some drow related traps for adventure-a-week, and was thinking of how to use drow sleepy poison. I think this is a good use. The characters enter a room with several bas-relief spiders on the wall. Each one shoots a drow sleepy dart at the party that also delivers a nightmare-like spell.

Interaction

 PFRPG:

D&D 4e:

Detect Trap Trigger

 

 

Very Hard Perception check.

same as PFRPG

Poison Dart

 

 

Very Hard Reflex Save or take 1d6 points of damage plus secondary attack. Secondary attack is Very Hard Fortitude Save or fall asleep for 2d4 rounds.

Very High Bonus Attack vs. Reflex or take 1d6 points of damage and secondary attack. Secondary Attack: Very High Bonus Attack vs. Fortitude or fall asleep for 2d4 rounds.

Nightmare

 

 

If asleep, Very High Will save or suffer 1d10 * APL damage, 1d6 Wisdom damage, become fatigued and lose all arcane spells for 24 hours.

If asleep, Very High Attack Bonus vs. Will or suffer 1d10 * APL damage, 1d6 Wisdom damage and lose all healing surges and all daily powers for 24 hours.

item.title: Levitate Accelerator (CR 4)
